number of helpful: 24 of 45 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Mislead by the screenshots into thinking that this would be a competent strategy game with an artistic flair; couldn't have been more wrong.  Gameplay is, at best, banal and repetitive.  Despite the appearance of strategy elements, the actual gameplay is primarily action-oriented -- that is once you can get past the tedious hand-holding tutorials.  What really drives it into the trash heap is the writing, cutscenes and VA.  Combat is primarily action-based, with a thin veneer of tactics on the surface.  Once you actually have some contol of the tactical aspect, you quickly realize how effectively limited your options are.  Most traps are ineffective and you end up using the same basic traps ad nauseam, in typically the same places every day.  The buildings that you are required to defend are apparently made out of rice paper, because a single wolf can destroy any structure located on the opposite side of the map in a matter of seconds, causing you to fail the night.I understand the gun mechanic is intended to supplement combat, but it's not enough to save you from the tedium of constantly running around and wildly swinning an axe.  The timing of events in combat is imprecise and slightly unresponsive.  The game is touted as being a variation on Tower Defense, but let's be clear:  Get used to swinging an axe, it's 80% of what you do.The writing is unbelievably bad.  It seems to be composed of lifeless tropes, clichés and hamfisted exposition.  The idioms are inappropriate and inconsistent with the setting, the characters are dimensionless, idiotic puppets playing out a callow farce.  Even the poor spelling, punctuation and  grammar exposes the lack of education and sloppy QC of the people involved.You're expected(?) to endure panel cutscenes at the beginning of each 'day' that foreshadow the subsequent combat scenario.  I cannot adequately describe how crass and farcical these scenes actually are, but subjectively speaking, they're awful.  Beyond the terrible writing, you have to listen to even-more-terrible voice acting.  The 'actors' mispronounce words everywhere (to almost comic effect), even inconsistently mispronouncing each other's names.  The characters are native to the story's setting, which is in northern [read: French] Canada, yet they manage still to mispronounce the names of Canadian cities.  Again, the 'actors' cannot even remotely keep their accents and idioms on target -- instead they meander all over the place, ranging from faux-British, to faux-Canadian, to Texan, to Mexican.  The female character central to the story is French-Canadian, pale skin, long red hair and -- get this -- voiced by a borderline-illiterate Hispanic woman.  The two protagonist brothers aren't voiced much better, either.  It's painful to listen to.Pros:  - Looks like a strategy RPG.  - 3/10 gameplay. Not the worst game on steam, sadly.Cons:  - Not a really strategy RPG.  - About as tactical as Gauntlet Legends.  - Traps are only a minor gimmic.  - Shallow, repetitive Hack-and-Slash gameplay.  - Controls are loose/laggy.  - Poor QC/QA.  - Awful writing/storyline.  - Terrible voice acting.  - Mostly comparable to a sloppy PS1-era fantasy action game.  - Almost shovelware.2/10:  Would not buy again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2013
												Essentially a tower defense game with some bells and whistles, similar to Dungeon Defenders. The game is two parts. Part 1 is planning for the wolf attacks at night in which you are able to see the waves, which enemies are attacking, and which paths they will take to a variety of buildings you are charged with protecting. Losing any of the buildings results in a failed night in which you must redo. Each type of wolf/werewolf has different stats, strengths, and weaknesses. You have a variety of traps that can be as simple as a bear or spike trap, or more complex, like a hanging net of rocks that you must shoot at when your prey is underneath. Each trap has either an Action Point cost, money cost, or both on it. These are the costs to set them on the map and limit the amount of things you can plop down on the gameboard. Leftover AP can be used to chop trees once you unlock the mill, thus providing you with more money for unused resources. Keep in mind though, once you do this, you can't use those points to buy extra damaging traps that can help you in the next mode. Once you start the night, you play Part 2 which plays out live action. You can pause the game in map mode, but as soon as the map drops, the wolves are coming.In addition, there are some interesting features in the game. For instance, you have a stamina bar. Of the two weapons you you start with (axe and rifle), you must be careful as to not tire yourself out. Running uses stamina as well. Also, when you run, you make more noise. Wolves are alert and can hear you the more noise you make. So, firing your gun obviously can alert them. You can also shout, which will call wolves to the last spot you shouted and (if they are close enough) cause them to fear you. Fear is an interesting feature in this game. Wolves will pace around while their fear wears down and then they attack you. You can yell to increase this, but eventually, the pack will attack. You can ward off wolves by building fires - they tend to not like these - and stand near them.But not for long. Fires wear out. You can take pot shots at them with your rifle, but reloading it requires you to tamp the shot with powder packets, so it's not like you're using a machine gun. Obviously, you can't do this under duress.After a successful night, you are graded on how many creatures you killed, the skins or parts you took from them (which gives you money), and how in tact the buildings are. XP and money is awarded (you also get money per kill in the game while playing in the live action mode). At this point you can go to town and buy more bullets, better weapons, gear to wear which gives effects, or potions and blessings from the local church on your items. You can also spend skill points in between levels in which you level up. Skill points accentuate your abilities, allowing you to rage for longer (an ability you naturally have while swinging your axe successfully), increase damage from weapons, set better traps, or reduce the time in between loading bullets. There are many skills to improve.The game has some flaws though. Firstly, the voice acting is really not all that great. The story isn't necessarily bad, but with poor voice acting, it really takes a back seat to just the gameplay.. which is fine. But it would have really brought the entire thing together to have a solid voice cast like in Bastion. The cut scenes are also pretty shoddy. I don't mean just in an amatuerishly drawn sense. Some of the models don't even look finished, especially when you look at how their fingers and hands work. When you play in the game, you don't see any of this. It's grossly glaring in the cut scenes however. And there were some minor annoyances, such as not being able to sell my starting gear once I improved it (it just stays in your inventory.. haven't figured out how to even scrap it). And, I have to travel back to my house to swap out new gear, then go back to town to sell it. I can't seem to do any of that in the buy/sell screen or in town. Minor frustrations.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												This game is a real gem and really deserves credit for it. It's really easy to get into and near impossible to master. Every day you have a new attack to defend yourself from with a set budget. I spent hours on some maps trying to save as much as possible while still beating the objectives in order to upgrade my gear sooner.So in a way I'd say that this is a money management/tower defence/stealth/action game. I have never played anything quite like it and that is the game's biggest strength. I'm not blown away by the graphics or the character designs though but they are solid and the game ages really well in my opinion. I should say though that the game is a pain to beat and the difficulty spikes pretty early. So if you are easily discouraged this game might not be for you. But I for one will come back to it more than once trying to optimise every level and be as rich as possible at the end credits. Just for fun of course!

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												9/10 - Just like in real life all your problems can be solved with alcohol and a good axe.The game is a mix between tower defence and third person action, pretty similar to Orcs Must Die, Dungeon Defenders and Sanctum. If you enjoyed any of these games you'll probably love Sang-Froid.Every night your house is attacked by waves of wolves and werewolves and you must set traps during the day to protect yourself when the night falls.The first few levels are meh, but as the game progress you'll be dying quite a lot of times each night until you can find the appropriate strategy for each level (especially if you're autistic like me and started the game on hard mode).The gameplay is divided in two parts, the planning mode during the day where you can buy stuff at stores, equip and level your character and spend money/time setting up traps on a overview map of the forest near your house, and the action part during the night, when you actually control your character around so you can ambush wolves with your axe and traps.Although the graphics are "dated" the game still looks fine. Simplistic, but better than most indie games out there.The OST is great, I mean, listen to the first video on the Steam store page. The background music always sets the perfect mood for whatever is happening. It's one of the strong points of the game.To sum it up, it's an amazing tower defense and action game, challenging as hell if you play on hard mode, great atmosphere and excellent game mechanics. Definitely worth the full price.

												Great game with some of the best introductory music ever.The game is based on Canadian folklore which makes an interesting setting for games. content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Sang-Froid is a terrific game which unfortunately suffers from not being particularly well known. The story won't have you on the edge of your seat but the key players are well written and likeable. As for the gameplay, it's an interesting blend of tower defense and a sort of hack and slash. Defend your buildings from the wolf hordes for as long as your traps hold out and then wade in with axe and rifle to finish the job. It's a terrific concept that consistently feels fresh with new traps and enemies unlocked every so often. Combine fantastic gameplay with two playable characters who play very differently from each other and some basic RPG elements to make the two even more unique and you have a very entertaining, very enjoyable gaming experience.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												To put my praise into one sentence: It's like this game is part 3 in a series. That is to say, it has so many interesting mechanics and ideas at work, you'd swear they were introduced over several games. But no -- somehow, Artifice has managed to come up with a half dozen new ideas all at once, and each builds on the last wonderfully.By far the most important is the "fear factor" -- this system really makes it feel like you're fighting a pack of wolves, unlike every other game where enemies just run up to you without thought. I never knew I wanted a "realistic" wolf fighting game before, but there you are.Aside from the gameplay, the music is impressive and catchy, but most other aspects do fall a little short. The graphics are dated and the voice actors aren't remotely up to the job. But the game itself is so different and fun that I can easily look past those flaws.My only other complaint is that with every stage introducting new things, there isn't much time to play around with each individual feature. It sounds odd to basically want filler, but having a second stage between each change would make it feel less rushed. On the other hand, it does contribute to an on-edge atmosphere, since you have to deal with the unknown every single level.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												Sang-Froid is an impressively complex RTS, with creative, realistic traps that remain grounded in the setting. Every level requires a careful plan, without a detail of the enemy's plan overlooked. The tension is palpable, as timing is everything: will the wolves finish the bait and move on your house before you've finished killing a werewolf clear on the other side of the map? How long do you have before the bonfire goes out and the pack closes in?Set in pre-Confederation Canada, the setting feels real and is well-maintained: every weapon, potion, trap and setpiece fits in the world. Even the prices are accurate to the time (eg. A bullet only costs a penny, and to bless them costs ten cents). Budgeting your money becomes another challenge; saving up for a better gun becomes difficult when you still have to worry about affording your silver bullets and spike traps to survive the next night.As a game, it is quite fun and exciting, but there are some issues with the presentation. The graphics are nothing pretty, but adequate. The music might wear on your nerves, depending on your taste, but like almost everything else, it is accurate to the time. There is one problem that stuck out, and that is the voice acting, which is bad enough that it falls noticably below the standards that every other aspect of the game meets. Despite the obvious setting, the characters do not speak with the proper accent, nor do they acknowledge the severity of the situation in their flat line-reading. My reccomendation would be to turn off the voices, and I'm thankful that the option is provided.Once the voices had been muted, I had a wonderful time with this game.

Posted: February 17, 2014
												This game is very good.  A lot of people say it's like Orcs Must Die, and while it is to some degree, I would have to say that it is much more strategic.  In the day you actually get to tactically lay out your traps (as opposed to OMD where you run around in 3rd person doing it between Waves) - you have information about each wave and a good idea how you want to set everything up.  The music is also really good.

Posted: July 14, 2014
												I purchased a bundle just to get this game, and I would have just as quickly bought this by itself.If you like strategy and tower defense games, you will really love Sang-Froid - the execution is fantastic.The aesthetics are very good and the music flows well with the theme and atmosphere. The controls are not too difficult to master, the tutorial videos are given quickly and right before each new mechanic (like new traps) is introduced. Recommend you do not skip these, as they are very helpful. The learning curve is not too bad, however, preplanning and strategy is critical to this game, and the game has a nice feature where you can restart at dawn or dusk (allowing you to restart with or without all your traps still on the field). The story is pretty decent, however, I must admit that the theme does not appeal to me very much (devil + his minions) - I've started skipping the cutscenes. Each "night" or level adds a layer of complexity, adding new traps, enemies, and areas of the map (the logging company will clear new areas every few levels). The upgrading tree offers a lot of different areas to select from to best match your preferred play style, and there are 2 characters to select from (one specializing in combat and the other in trap-laying and strategy). You can go to town to buy new weapons, bless your weapons/buy blessed bullets (to do extra damage to "evil" enemies), and later you have the option of buying silver weapons (to use against the Maikans {wolf humanoids; distinct from werewolves}). In the preplanning screen, you can select traps to use. These all cost action points, however, the ones that also cost money are permanent and will persist through the nights so long as they are not used. You can also click on the wave tabs to see which enemies you will be encountering. A very useful feature is your sister's precognition, which will show you where your enemies will travel if you click their tab - this is essential for planning where to place your traps. As you progress, you will unlock more buildings that provide more AP to your pool, however, they also provide more targets for your enemies. You lose if any building is destroyed.There are many cool mechanics during gameplay, one being wind and shouting. Wind affects where your scent can be detected, and shouting also pulls all enemies from a large radius. You unlock a talisman later in the game that allows you to manipulate where the wind is blowing - very useful for pulling enemies from an even larger radius than shout. A red icon shows where enemies will look for you, and you can use this to lure them to your traps (like spike traps or hanging nets {with rocks}). Fear factor is a very interesting concept, and enemies will attack you when their fear factor matches yours. This allows you to control the flow of combat - so long as your fear factor is higher (like when you are near a fire) than your enemy's, they will be less likely to attack you right away. Werewolves have a bloodlust ability that gives them infinite fear factor (aka aggro). Attacking and defeating enemies will lower their fear factor, and there are items that further increase your own (like necklaces and potions/drinks).The game runs incredibly well, and it is extremely fun to plan out how to best deal with your enemies - especially in the later nights when different groups and waves will target different buildings. Investing in zip line towers is critical to increasing your mobility. There are also fire walls, and these are integral to survival because they will force enemies to reroute (to potentially longer routes), buying you more time to deal with your priorities. Blocking enemies off completely will cause them to take the shortest route (and the damage). Any leftover AP you have can be used to cut wood, providing you much needed money. Maximizing your trap efficiency and wood cutting will ensure that you have a of money to spend on weapon upgrades and other equipment.If you are interested at all or enjoy TD-games, you have to give this a try. It is one of the best TD-games I have come across.Strongly recommend!

Posted: July 13, 2014
												This is not your typical Tower Defense game.  The action involves both placing traps, then some 3rd person melee fighting.  Your axe is your primary method of taking out the beasts.  You do get a musket to use and can load it with blessed (costs extra) slugs, but with the slowness of loading and getting the gun ready, it is by no means a "Primary Weapn".  The gun is there to be used as a mobile trap and only while the mobs are still afraid of you.This game is not "Action Packed", there are a ton of speed bumps here.  While the cut scenes provide a dialog and story that isn't found in other TD games and I apprecaite that, it does feel "slowing" to me.  Much of the game is spent going to town to spend your pennies (wisely), setting up your traps, working out a strat or wrapped up in dialog.  The battle-time where you're running around swinging your axe winds up being cut down to maybe 10% of the overall game time.   (Note: I didn't time it out to verifiy "10%" but it feels like very little time, goes by quickly.)If you try to go back and replay a map, you lose all of your progress.   So you can't replay "Day 3" with "Day 7" gear.  Again, this is "Forced Story-Line" gameplay.  You can't muck that up with better weapons/traps.  It would be nice to be able to do that though, since you could gain XP and Cash to make moving forward easier.This is a good Stategic Thinking trainer though.  You really do have to plan out your night, where you're going to run and when.   You have unlimited time to sit there planning out your trap placement and sequence of movements.   (Stay at farm for wave 1, move to the chicken coop for wave 2... etc.)  The Zip Line is an excellent addition for movement though, you will greatly appreciate that tower!  Walking is slow and running burns your stamina too quickly.Overall, I give it a Thumbs Up, but for the reasons listed above I'm going to say "buyer be aware".

Also, no reason to NOT pick the huge lumberjack brother as you'll just get murdered because of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat system using the other guy.I wouldn't recommend it full price, then again if I could go back in time i'd stop myself from wasting my time as well soo....

Posted: December 15, 2013
												The graphics, voice acting and story all leave something to be desired, but where it lacks in those categories it more than makes up in unique and genuinely fun gameplay. It's a diamond in the rough. If you can look past the aesthetics that everyone clings to these days, and think of it more as an early stage of this type of game, it's truly fantastic. I'd like to see it with the polish it deserves, but even without it you're bound to have a good time. If you like strategy games, but also have that part of you that loves to smash through enemies in beat-em-up style, you're getting the best of both worlds with Sang-Froid. As I said above, it's a diamond in the rough, so not everything is seamless, though it's very close.All in all, for $15 you're getting a lot more bang for your buck than the same old game that's been coming out the last 15 years and wants $60.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												I've barely scratched the surface of this game, having played a paltry 78 minutes at the time of writing, but I've enjoyed this more than quite a few of my recent steam purchases (and they cost double the full price of this gem!).This is a twist on the tower defence genre that I haven't seen before; third person hack & slash combat, with traps that trigger in a variety of ways. During the day you can stock up on supplies and buy shiney new weapons, then plan your strategy and place your traps in order to survive the coming night's wolf attack, then survive said wolf attack!For the £1.10 I paid for this in a flash sale yesterday I've struck absolute gold. I'd have happily paid full price.

Posted: June 8, 2014
												Just about an hr and a half into the tower defense game, Sang Froid Tales of Werewolves, and for $1.50 or 90% off asking price, this was a steal!! I kept my expectations very low. I thought, why would a $15 game be discounted more than 50%? I had to find out. It's about hunting werewolves! That alone had me interested. The story is about 2 brothers Jack and Jos, at odds with each other but have to work together to help save their sister Josephine, who is possessed by some evil spirit. You have to choose one of the brothers to control. Jack is the more strategic character that lays traps (according to the game difficulty, it's hard). Jos is the stronger of the two, an effective melee attacker (game difficulty, it's easy) to which I'm assuming that he has a bigger health bar. I chose Jack to play.What I was surprised about SF was how much you can do. From basic combat with wolves and werewolves, to planning out strategies to take on waves of enemies (mostly wolves and werewolves). Each successful night, gives you XP to improve your character, weapons, and traps. You can go up to level 15. Very well designed maps, menus, tutorials, and screens. The art direction follows more of the comic cut out look during the cutscenes. And it's nicely done. The controls are not the best, but very manageable. You can use a melee weapon from up close and ranged weapons from a distance. The best part about the combat is that you can use both types without overusing one or the other. I haven't played much strategy/base defense games before. The closest that I can think of is Assassin's Creed Revelation's tower defense (which was a bad addition to the franchise). Sang Froid Tales of Werewolves is a very good tower defense game. Get this game before the deal while on sale.

Posted: July 7, 2014
												The game is very unique. Similar to Orcs Must Die, this game has a refreshing take on the tower defense genre. You set up traps and plan before the waves begin, and fight in 3rd person to activate and attack the wolf creatures. The music is good, graphics are decent, gameplay is smooth and has plenty of depth, and is worth the price.

The idea for this game is great, and while it's game is a tad sluggish in it's execution, it by no means fails. Highly Recommended.

Posted: February 6, 2015
												First off I reccomend this game entirely to anyone who enjoy's the following.Werewolves.Good story.Tactical gaming.A challenge.If all of the above topics appeal to you  I believe you will enjoy this game.What I like about it. (Spoiler-Maybe?)Firstly I like the story/topic. Two brothers trying to survive and protect their ill sister as werewolve's and other creatures  descend upon them. The topic "werewolve's" it's an easy place to make a rich story and as you get farther in the game it becomes so.This game does and does not hold your hand, You are explained everything in great detail and taught how to play the game but it is wholey up to you to excecute what you have been taught and at certain times flawlessly. it really leads you calmly into the woods then leaves you to the wolves. The gameplay is exillerating! you plan out everything all of your traps, what weapon's you will use, where the enemy is coming from, what type of enemy and how many there will be before nightfall. You plan and learn as you play the game and you are forced to do so. Then when night comes you see if your tactic and preperation payed off, Did you miss something? or forget something? Did your traps work like you imagined they would? did you bring enough silver or blessed bullets? you find out quickly if what you had done the day before was enough to help you through the grizzly night.You purchase items from the town and other places to help you against the varied and versatile creatures. You start with a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor woodsman's axe and an old musket, They get the job done for a while but not for too long at least not in the state they're in. So you look to upgrade, Walking into the blacksmith's shop you spot a nice looking lumberjacks axe that put's your  current affair to shame' however... It cost's 5 dollars! tripple your current allowance for shiny axes. feeling crummy and that the world is against you you walk into a chapel to angrilly pray at god! But as you enter a nun approaches and seeing your axe she offers to bless it with holy power effectivly doubling it's current strength she'll bless you'r normal style bullet's too. Suddenly that crap axe is looking pretty swell and your musket doesn't make you want to use it to shoot yourself in the head.This game does a really good job at pulling you in, At least it did for me. At first I didn't know what to think playing the first few chapters I was let's say... unimmpressed.  but as I progressed I was compelled to continue and the more I played the more I felt that way, That drive didn't wear off for me and it still hasn't.What I don't like about it.Bug's they are in every game and I hate them! (Unless they're funny)What I like about it.Everything else! I can say that I like just about everything in this game I really have no bad to say about it. But that's just me. Anyone reading this is their own critic as it should be, You're just looking for some insight on a game. But I know and you know that it doesn't really matter what I or anyone else sais, What matter's is how you feel when you play the game.Thank's for reading.P.S. this game has a demo! simply search "Sang-Froid" on steam and give it a go!

Posted: June 3, 2014
												Here we have a fantastic game with a compelling story, rich atmosphere and a unique feel from its stylized graphics and original soundtrack. The opening music alone is worth the current sale price ($1.49-almost as much as a song on iTunes), although I'd recommend this game even without a discount. 1850s Canada is quite the refreshing setting, an unfamiliar time and place that only adds to the unfolding mystery.Sang-Froid definitely has an indie feel to it-especially with the cutscenes-but the gameplay mechanics are intuitive and solid. I love the different stages in each level, from placing traps and planning a defense during the day to executing your plan come nightfall, for better or for worse. There's this sense of escalating urgency to the whole thing, as if there's just not enough time or resources to make it through to the next day.In one instance I stood upwind from a pack and heard their howls as they caught and followed my scent. I snared an oncoming werewolf in a bear trap and crushed it to death with a quick shot to the overhanging rock pile I'd placed, then I frantically ran from its companions back to a bonfire by the cabin, rolling this way and that out of their clawing reach, barely able to light the fire before running out of stamina, and just able to frighten the beasts to catch a quick breather before axing them all to death in a ferocious back-and-forth dance around the fire-only to have to sprint right over to the next building in a panic to catch more of the werewolves before they could finish tearing everything to rubble. Exhilarating!highly recommended!

Posted: June 5, 2014
												I've barely scratched the surface of this game, having played a paltry 78 minutes at the time of writing, but I've enjoyed this more than quite a few of my recent steam purchases (and they cost double the full price of this gem!).This is a twist on the tower defence genre that I haven't seen before; third person hack & slash combat, with traps that trigger in a variety of ways. During the day you can stock up on supplies and buy shiney new weapons, then plan your strategy and place your traps in order to survive the coming night's wolf attack, then survive said wolf attack!For the £1.10 I paid for this in a flash sale yesterday I've struck absolute gold. I'd have happily paid full price.

Posted: June 3, 2014
												I highly enjoyed Sang-Froid because you get to kill demonic and mystical wolves in the name of chivalry. The gameplay was very intuitive but the well narrated and detailed tutorials were much appreciated after skipping them initially only to view them later for the sake of completeness.Also, the highly responsive gameplay, well-rounded gameplay mechanics (trap placement , skill trees, etc. )  and trap\weapon arsenal kept the experience fresh until the end, which is the only gripe I have with Sang-Froid.After the end, the choices are limited on how to proceed in the current campaign. You cannot repeat previous levels in the campaign without consequences. If you want to go back to a certain day, you lose all the progress made after that point. In addition to fixing that flaw, this game severely needs an "Endurance Mode" and another mode that features randomization of the enemy's attack patterns. My issues with the game still shouldn't dissuade you from purchasing Sang-Froid -- even at full price -- because it is more than worth it.

Posted: June 13, 2014
												This game is hard, yet fair with tense as hell combat and a lot of room for strategic use of traps. The atmosphere is superb. The voice acting is lack luster, buck this is an issue I can easily look past, especially considering how much fun I had. This game demands a sequel both to straighten out some of the kinks and just so I can play more.Edit: Oh! I didn't even mention the music! It's just wonderful and it really adds to the overall feel of this game. I love it.

Posted: June 13, 2014
												Where do i begin. I had $2 left in my account from an ealier purchase. This game was on sale. Why not?, i thoughy to my self as i clicked the purchase button. I finally got to play it after 2 days. Long story short, best game i have played in a while. Definitely up there with Brothers: A Tale Of Two Sons. The music is  the best i have ever heard in any game. Especially the one during the loading screen. If you want a fun not so hardcore game, 100% get this one. The gameplay is also easy, well at the beginning. It's all about planning and using your head. I could go on for ages but I 100% recommend this game to any gamer out there. Won't dissapoint. I promise :)

Posted: October 10, 2013
												This sh.it is AWESOME. Every new «mission» is divided into the daytime, when you plan your defence, place the traps, and buy stuff, and the night, when you act, defending your buildings. Between normal and hard choose hard — the game will appear quite difficult, but that's what you came for. Though there are a lot of parameters, traps, items, etc., you'll find yourself well-informed about every new feature, after watching short but informative video tutorials, appearing all along in your adventure. The best thing about this game is that you have to plan (during the day) every your move, and try to keep the sequence of your further acts together in your head (during the night). Meanwhile, it's not just a mind game, where you plan-and-execute... Actually, the «execution» part is made of real action, filled with suddenness, emotional experience and adrenaline.A rare gameplay masterpiece. 92 out of 100.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Although I'm not usually one for the tower defence genre, I was happily lured in by the setting of Sang-Froid. What other game takes you to Quebec in 1858? You play as one of two brothers who are both good men at heart but somewhat troubled and not particularly liked by civilization. When your sister falls ill after being run out of town by a two-faced priest, the tiny cabin you hole up in becomes full of family turmoil and the epicentre of attacks by possessed wolves and more. Family woes aren't exactly put aside as monsters come night after night, giving a great feel for the brothers.Gameplay is a merge of tower defence and third person action. During the day you go to town to buy booze, weapons, and gear and set up all sorts of traps from simple wolf traps to hanging nets of rocks to much more elaborate tools like spring-loaded spikes and ballistas. As is often the case, you unlock more and more goodies and more routes and more places to defend as you rely on a mix of trapping and just beating things with an axe or shooting a musket. Depending on how you spend your skills every level can also help out your preference of play.So with a unique setting, variable gameplay, a great soundtrack, and enjoyment all round, if you remotely like tower defence and/or third person action, Sang-Froid is a must!

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												This was a tough one. This game has lovely art, great controls, a fun combination of strategy and action, and an enchanting mythology set in old Canada. A plague of possessed wolves and werewolves begin attacking a small Canadian village and two estranged brothers, one a trapper and one a lumberjack, must unite to protect their beloved sister as the Devil seeks to claim her for his own. Imagine "Orcs Must Die" mixed with "The Howling" and "The Exorcist"! It's glorious! But after less than an hour, I had to stop playing and uninstall it because, honestly, I love wolves. For whatever reason i feel a deep kinship with them, and being required by a game to kill nothing BUT wolves -- wolves which react realistically and whimper when hit -- was beyond the pale for me. Nevermind the fact that these wolves are possessed by the Devil, acting entirely out of character (which the game, to its credit, repeatedly acknowledges) and mutating into hideous anthropoid forms -- you're still killing wolves. I can't bear it. I recommend this game highly, but not if you are as viscerally attached to lupines as I am. If you don't mind fighting demon-wolves for the soul of your family? PLAY THIS!

												This game is a different kind of tower defence. You use the night to set up traps to kill or impede the werewolves and other beasts, and then you have to finish what's left off yourself.This requires you to plan and make a strategy each night, which is really cool, thinking about how best to lure the max amout of werewolves into the most efficient trap and how many you can beat with your axe to save money.The story is charming and the game oozes charm and atmosphere, though the voice acting is fairly bad.If you want a different kind of tower defence game, and want to beat up werewolves with an axe, then this is the game for you!

Amazing Indie Game! First watched the trailer, thought it seemed like an interesting game, and hey! It was very cheap! Didn't  have high expectations, but damn was I foolish to have that, because this game was really good!Starting the game and up comes the loading screen. Suddenly a playful tune turns on, which was this amazing cool soundtrack. Didn't even bother that the loading screen was long, since the soundtrack was so fun to listen to. Playing trough the game and I still enjoy the soundtracks. The traps are cool, and it really seems that the developers has put a lot of thought into the traps and their purpose. And little did I know that they had so many different creatures. Planning a strategy for each wave and could never use the same strategy twice really made my head ache. Really fun! At the final stages of the game I had to actually write down my strategy to remember because it got so complex. Very few games has done that for me, and that is a really good thing. One also had to thing ahead to make short tactics for one day and long strategies for days ahead.The story was well thought trough, and was really compelling. Enjoy it a lot. The graphics really fit the consept of the game and usually I'm a "grapichs ♥♥♥♥♥" and just play games with great graphics, but with this game I didn't bother at all since it was so giving.MUST BUY if you like Tower-Defense Third-person Shooter RPG! Or simply just buy it no mather what because this game was outstanding!Really looking forward to  eventually a sequal or  a new game from these developers :D

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												Interesting fusion of strategy, tower defence and 3rd person action wrapped up with a quirky theme which is overall an enjoyable experience and worth a look if you want something different!The game has you taking the role of one of two brothers defending initially their cabin, but eventually a number of buildings and locations throughout a forest from ever increasing waves of wolves, werewolves and other mythical  creatures. Gameplay is split into two phases: Day Phase: This is basically the 'setup' you are presented with a map of the forest showing the spawn locations, number and targets of the various enemies you will face during the night. From here you can set traps, or place other structures to help you survive the night. You can visit shops to buy new equipment which the money you earn and spend skill points which are unlocked by levelling up your character to give you bonus abilities. Night Phase: During the night you must take control of your character to enact you plan by running around the forest, springing the traps you have set and taking on the enemies in combat (both gun based and melee). The game provides a good variety of enemies, each with different strengths and weaknesses to plan for, and a range of traps allowing you to pick your tactics. The 'Lumberjack' theme is nicely carried through the game in the art style of the menus and the soundtrack. The 3rd person combat is a little clunky, but is designed to keep you thinking tactically rather than just charging into a group with your axe. The game certainly has negative points which might put some people off. The story is overly complicated, fairly non-nonsensical and unnecessary. The voice acting/dialogue in the cut-scenes isn't amazing and in general I didn't like the way it was told, mostly in dull dialogue between characters. Occasionally there would be a cut scene represented in a kind of hand-drawn animation style (completely different to everything else) which actually worked really well and I can't help but think the game designers should have had a simpler story, but stuck to this style. The loading times are also quite long and although you can restart a mission at 'dusk' with all your traps in the same place, you still have to go back to the planning screen, start the night, go through the inventory screen, wait for the level to load  and click through any cut-scenes before you can make another attempt at a mission you failed, which gets annoying if you make a few mistakes early on in a mission.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2013
												Sangfroid is an action-tower defence game, like Orcs Must Die, but with more emphasis on tactical planning. It has some neat ideas that provide a fresh experience within the genre. You're a 19th century Canadian lumberjack, and your home is under attack by werewolves and other mystical creatures. Each level is split into two parts, day and night. During the day you can see which enemies you'll face, and which path they'll take. You can place traps, spend XP on upgrades, and visit town to buy weapons and equipment. Then you fight at night, using your traps and 3rd person combat. You can't place any new traps, your gun reloads slowly and melee attacks reduce your stamina. But this is good, because it really forces you to think ahead and carefully plan every move. The difficulty curve is nicely balanced. The story is good, but sadly the voice acting is awful, and graphics are not fantastic. Its very stable, and I got 9 hours from one playthrough, so I'm happy with value for money.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I enjoy it when a game designer approaches a pre-existing genre from a new, flavorful perspective. For example, I think it would be neat if we could get rid of the zombies in a lot of these survival/horror games and instead put the players against mummies in Egypt.So how did I react when I saw that Sang Froid was a tower defense game, set in the Great White North, where you must protect a house with an axe and a musket from waves of werewolves sent by the devil? My reaction could be summed up in one word: SOLD!Sangfroid (pronounced san-frwa) is a french word for “the ability to stay calm in difficult or dangerous situations.” This game requires exactly that.  Most games give you relatively fast recharge time or a clip for you gun rounds, so you can afford to miss shots occasionally.  In Sang-Froid, you have to reload your musket after every shot.  In many instances, you have to stall the wolves while you reload your musket, and you have to build that time into your gameplan and make every shot count. You have a lot to do and a short time to do it, but the key thing is that you keep calm and carry on.I once heard this genre referred to as a “boots on the ground tower defense game,” and I think that’s an apt description.  It reminds me a little bit of Brutal Legend; I even remember thinking during one mission “this does to tower defense what Brutal Legend attempted to do with RTS, but it does it right.”  After reading other reviews, I have seen the game compared to Orcs Must Die and/or Sanctum.  If they are anything like Sang Froid, I am excited about giving them a try.While Sang Froid requires timing, I wouldn’t call it a twitch game.  That said, it is one where you have to remain alert to the larger danger while keeping your attention on the specific task at hand.  The stages were hard, but satisfying.  whenever I finished one, I felt like Hannibal from the A-Team. ("I love it when a plan comes together.")The overall flavor to the game is light, campy, with a good story and just the right amount of cheese.  The game constantly changes graphical styles between game play, cut scenes, and dialog. If I wasn’t such a fan of Ralph Bakshi’s animation I would likely find this quite jarring. I wouldn’t be surprised if other people found this annoying.The digital storytelling technique used in the game serves as a reminder that it is a low budget title, but I think that added to the overall charm of the game.  The characters appearing and disappearing during dialog reminds me of the dialog from Guild Wars 2 or Aqua Teen Hunger Force. The folk-style soundtrack makes me think of what country music must have sounded like before country music existed; it keeps the player in the moment, but remained light enough to keep it from feeling like a horror game.Sang Froid is an excellent tower defense game with a lot of charm and an interesting story.  Give it a try.

												I realized the true potential of this game just as I saw it in the GreenLight. Well, this game is really worthwhile! Strategic and roleplay features make incredible atmosphere of a folk horror tale, which is supported with a fantastic soundtrack. Highly recomended!Advatages:1) Comfortable system of strategic planning and fiendly interface.2) Wonderful roleplay system: without an odd complexity, but with a good variety.3) Enchanting soundtrack!4) Very realistic gameplay: we get money from selling wolves' fur and lumbering (gold doesn't run out from killed enemies instead of blood)5) All the cinematics could be skipped.Disadvantages:1) I agree that the style of graphics makes the spirit of the game, but some models could be much smoothy.Потенциал этой игры я понял, когда голосовал за неё в GreenLight. Но, как это у меня заведено, ждал скидок 50+ %. Игра оправдала ожидания. Стратегические и ролевые моменты на высоте, адреналина в драках тоже хватает.Плюсы:1) Хорошая система планирования ловушек и удобный интерфейс.2) Отличная ролевая система. Не замороченная, как это любят в современных играх, но достаточно разнообразная, чтобы выбрать свой стиль игры.3) Очень приятный саундтрек.4) Продуманные детали сюжета и геймплея. Например, деньги мы получаем от продажи шкур и от работы на вырубке (а не собираем брызнувшее из чудовищ, как  сок из ягод, золото)5) Почти все ролики и заставки можно пропустить.Минусы:1) Графика, конечно, могла бы быть и получше. Хотя, отчасти такая прорисовка добавляет атмосферности.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Very rarely do I write reviews for games but I felt this one deserved it. This game takes several elements from my favorite genres (RPGs, Strategy, Action/Adventure) and puts them all into one very well-done package. The decisions you make when leveling and planning your strategies are tough and have real consequences on the outcome of the game. Often times you are on your toes trying to get from one place to another on the map and the sense of urgency during the nights you are trying to survive is persistent and effective. The story was very interesting and keep me playing. I almost beat this game in one sitting to find out what was happening. It is a unique and dark story line set in the late 1850s and the time period and setting really add to the story being told. Gameplay elements are good, there are a few small bugs but nothing that really got in my way of enjoying the game. The graphics are simple but they work-it is an indie game but deserves way more attention. There are hand-drawn cutscenes from time to time that add to the experience. You will hear several people talk about the music in this game and let me say they are not wrong in stating it is excellent. I loved it so much I tracked down the artists online and will be buying the albums. They are all French so it was a bit of a hunt but the music is so good it didn't bother me. I hope to see a sequel to this at some point. I would highly recommend this game, especially when on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
http://lantredugeek.com/pc-sang-froid-un-conte-de-loups-garous/Qu'est-ce que ce jeu?Le principe de base de Sang-Froid est assez simple; les deux frères devront protéger leur sœur contre les hordes de monstres que le diable leur envoie la nuit. Pour ce faire, ils devront utiliser l'environnement qui les entoure à leur avantage et préparer de savants pièges et outils qui leur permettront de tenir une nuit de plus. Passons au travers des quelques éléments qui constituent ce magnifique jeu; 


YouTube™ Video: Bande-annonce de Sang-Froid - un conte de loups-garous 

			Views: 6,473		

			Nouvelle bande-annonce du jeu vidéo indépendant Sang-Froid - un conte de loups-garous, dont l'histoire a été co-écrite avec Bryan Perro, l'auteur d'Amos Daragon et de Wariwolf.		

 Les deux frères / niveaux de difficultéSangFroid_Feuille-PersonnageEn commençant votre partie, vous aurez le choix de jouer l'un des deux frères (Jacques "Ti-Jack" et Joseph "Ti-Jos" O'Carroll). Les deux frères représentant les deux niveaux de difficulté du jeu; Facile/Difficile. En jouant avec Jacques O'Carroll (le mode difficile), vous serez un chasseur agile et rusé. Vous devrez faire preuve d'ingéniosité à l'aide de vos trappes et de votre fusil de chasse, étant plus faible physiquement que votre autre frère, la ruse sera votre meilleure arme! En jouant avec Joseph O'Carroll (le mode facile), vous serez un fier bûcheron fort et robuste. Vos coups de hache seront forts et puissants, il est également important de remarquer vous aurez beaucoup plus de facilité à résister aux attaques de vos ennemis. Les deux personnages auront accès aux mêmes actions, objets et arbres de compétences. Cependant, les différences se joueront au niveau de la résistance physique, de la force de frappe avec la hache, de la précision aux armes à feu ainsi que l'agilité de chaque personnage. Tandis que l'un sera beaucoup plus résistant, l'autre devra garder ses distances. Et alors que l'un possède une meilleure maîtrise de l'arme à feu, l'autre devra se préférer l'utilisation de sa fidèle hache. La phase de préparations (le jour)SangFroid_Jour-MonstresLe jour, c'est votre période de préparation. Vous aurez accès à une carte détaillée de l'environnement dans lequel vous allez combattre. Sur ladite carte régionale, vous aurez la possibilité de voir des cartes de monstre vous permettant de planifier vos défenses grâce aux prédictions de votre petite sœur, Joséphine. Ces cartes vous permettront de connaître chaque type de monstre, l'endroit d'où ceux-ci débuteront leur attaque, leur trajectoire ainsi que leur but final. Une mission se déroule généralement sur deux tours (ou plus), les prévisions de Joséphine vous permettront également de connaître d'avance l'ordre d’apparition des monstres pour chaque tour.SangFroid_Jour-TrappesPour vous défendre contre les monstres, vous aurez la possibilité de placer des pièges de toutes sortes pour vous aider dans votre tâche; appâts pour ralentir certaines créatures, feux-de-joie pour effrayer certaines créatures, murs de feu pour changer la trajectoire de vos ennemis, trappes-à-ours, et plus encore! Chaque monstre possède ses faiblesses, et ce sera votre travail de savoir quels pièges sont les plus appropriés aux situations dans lesquelles vous vous retrouverez. Pour installer un piège ou une installation, vous devriez utiliser vos sous ainsi que vos points d'action. Après un certain point dans le jeu, vous serez dans la mesure d'échanger vos points d'action contre des sous supplémentaires en coupant du bois.SangFroid_Magasin-GeneralPendant la préparation de vos défenses pour la nuit, vous aurez également la chance de visiter le village de Val-aux-loups afin de faire quelques emplettes aux différents magasins du village. Vous pourrez y acheter armes, balles pour vos armes à feu, objets de guérison, etc. Afin de pouvoir faire vos achats, vous devrez utiliser les sous que vous aurez amassé au courant de vos dernières aventures. (Vous aurez des sous pour chaque monstre que vous aurez tué, pour chaque mission complétée, ou bien en vendant du bois.)Une fois que vous êtes préparés, il ne vous reste plus qu'à attendre que la nuit se lève. La phase de combat (la nuit)SangFroid_NuitEt la nuit, c'est là que l'action commence! Vous aurez un petit laps de temps pour déplacer votre personnage là où vous le souhaitez avant que la première vague d'attaque ne commence. Par la suite, vous devrez vous assurer que chaque créature a bien été tuée pour sauter à l'étape suivante. Pour ce faire, vous pourrez activer certaines trappes manuellement (pièges de roches suspendues, feux-de-joie, etc.) ou bien attaquer les créatures directement à l'aide de votre hache et de votre fusil.En combat, vous pourrez courir et sauter, faire des roulades pour esquiver les attaques, lancer de puissants cris pour attirer les créatures au loin ou effrayer les créatures tentant de vous attaquer, attaquer vos ennemis à coups de hache, tirer à coups de fusil, utiliser les objets que vous aurez achetés au magasin ou même tomber en rage quelques secondes afin d'asséner des coups encore plus puissants aux monstres qui veulent votre peau. Faites attention à votre barre d'énergie; chaque fois que vous faites une action physique (coup de hache, courir, rouler, etc.), vous utiliserez une certaine quantité d'énergie. Une fois la barre vidée, vous serez exténué, et deviendrez une proie facile. Il est important de prendre de petites pauses lorsqu'il est possible pour éviter que cela n'arrive!Une fois que vous aurez anéanti toutes les vagues de monstres, vous aurez complété la mission. Vos récompenses en sous vous seront alors distribuées, et vous pourrez attaquer le prochain jour pour de nouveaux défis. Il est important de noter que chaque nuit apporte de nouveaux monstres ou de nouvelles possibilités/mécaniques de jeu qui vous demanderont de pouvoir vous adapter rapidement. Qualité graphique, artistique et sonoreSangFroid_ChargementCertes, les graphismes du jeu ne sont pas les plus beaux, et ce, même si vos paramètres sont au maximum. Les modèles utilisés pour représenter les personnages et les créatures font un boulot très convenable et du moins, le jeu n'est pas laid. L'ambiance générale et le style artistique de Sang-Froid nous permettent d'oublier très facilement les quelques lacunes côté modélisation, textures et animations. SangFroid_DiscussionsMalgré le style artistique intéressant de Sang-Froid, le jeu possède une grosse lacune côté doublage. Malgré le fait que les voix francophones utilisent un français d'antan (ce qui facilite l'immersion d'ailleurs), nous avons l'impression que les acteurs lisent directement un livre sans regarder l'animation des personnages. Également, il est important de noter qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup de cinématiques dans le jeu, le jeu utilisant plus ou moins le même principe que les jeux de "nouvelles interactives" où l'image des personnages est placée au-dessus d'une boîte de texte. Seule différence est que chaque texte est accompagné d'une voix, et que l'image est remplacée par un modèle 3D quelque peu animé. ConclusionSang-Froid est la preuve que le Québec est capable de grandes choses dans le monde du jeu vidéo. Le petit studio indépendant d'Artifice Studios a su créer un petit bijou que tous les amateurs de jeux de stratégie devraient se procurer. L'univers utilisé pour le jeu est unique et utilise une époque peu exploitée par l'industrie, ce qui lui donne un charme exceptionnel. La qualité graphique du jeu est un peu basse, mais le style artistique de celui-ci nous fait rapidement oublier ces quelques lacunes. Le jeu ne possède pas de modes multijoueurs, mais offre tout de même un excellent facteur plaisir. Nous vous conseillons de vous le procurer dès maintenant!HISTOIRE/NARRATION - 8.5UNIVERS/CONSISTANCE - 10PERSONNAGES/ENNEMIS - 9QUALITÉ GRAPHIQUE - 8QUALITÉ SONORE - 9QUALITÉ INTELLIGENCE ARTFICIELLE - 8.5FACTEUR REJOUABILITÉ - 7.5FACTEUR DIFFICULTÉ - 7FACTEUR INNOVATION - 8.5

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Despite the rough graphics and voice-acting, despite the hack & slash being lacking, it blends together with a rich atmosphere, capable RPG elements and ingenious strategic compentents to come together as a deeply clever and immersive game that has no equals in a genre it has created all by itself: Which I'd like to call Strategic Action Defense. In essence, the game is a unique, ingenious bland between a rudimentary third person hack&slash and a clever (tower) defense game in the most strategic sense possible. Anyone would be excused for thinking of isometric Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA) games like LOL or DOTA, or Orcs Must Die where the combat is hectic, constant, fast paced and deals with hundreds of mindless mobs marching towards your side, but Sang-Froid is not. Instead the action is tense, tactical, clever and far more personal.Every game, you start off with a top down perspective of a pine forest through which snowy trails wind towards your cabin. They're paths taken by an onslaught of wolves out to tear it down. This is the planning phase. At first, you just need to defend the cabin where your sick sister lies, but soon the barn, mill, church and more buildings get added to the community under your care. Your sister is a special kind of sick however. She can see from where the wolves are coming to attack those buildings and what routes they'll take, through visions.This is where the first difference between the game and others like it become apparant: It's personal. When you choose to leave the planning stage and enter the world, the third person hack&slash ensures that your character is the most versatile weapon you have and there really aren't that many wolves, especially in the beginning. Its just that the wolves are capable of coming in from anywhere and your character is just one man with a tiny bar of stamina that can't possibly cover the large stretches of space between buildings AND safely fight more than a few wolves at the same time. And when you do choose to engage, the wolves aren't fodder either. They really are characters in their own right.Personal combat is involving. Should they have all pounced at once, they would have torn you apart, but a complex system of fear and intimidation, using roars, fires and actions, will see them circling while you deal with those few who manage the courage to take swipes at you. You are are armed with axe and rifle, but the axe will quickly sap your stamina and your rifle is an antique that requires 10 seconds of loading. Tougher foes arrive by themselves or in pairs, but these are often so durable that they take just as much time as any one of those packs.Combat is a long process against worthy foes then, but time isn't something you have as more packs all over the map close in on your buildings.This is where the traps come in, and a good deal of patience and savvy from you. Using the planning phase ahead of the third person action phase, allows you to not only prepare your own community through the purchase of gear, but to prepare a strategy for dealing with all of these packs at the same time. And instead of just placing down towers that splash the occasional damage, these traps are of the visceral, personal kind, suited to dealing with a foe that would have given you so much trouble in melee.Bearclaws will instantly kill the four legged wolves. Bait attracts and slows them down, giving you precious extra time. Placing nets with an avalanche of rocks in them high among the treetops, will bury werewolves when timed right. Place kindle in certain passages and set it alight to redirect packs.Some of these traps work automatic. Others are far more involving. The net trap for example, needs to be triggered by a shot from your rifle, preferably after luring the werewolf underneath through the use of deception: Bait or a shout to lure it there.If there's one thing the game does exceedingly well, it is to establish the relationship between hunter and hunted, or making you feel like a rugged outdoors man triumphing over nature through wit. You are keenly aware of just how frightful and tough a werewolf can be in combat, so seeing it carried off through the air on the sharp tip of a ballista bolt after you've personally set it off and tricked the wolf in the right position is a gleeful moment. The transfer between planning phase where you control the map, and action phase where your control is limited to the range of your gun is a disempowering one. The map is tidy, but on foot, the mill is a world away. All you could do is set some spike traps around it, only to realize you couldn't do the same for the werewolf you are about to face for lack of cash. There's only a bonfire for him, to keep him back. "Will it work?" You will wonder.In such a moment, a sudden swish-click-yelp sound in the far distance of the frozen wintersky, will make you smile as you keep warm around the lit bonfire.Other than this, the game itself has charm too. Its not a looker, with somewhat decent animation and bearable graphics. Sometimes, the voice acting is cringe-worthy too, with a cast of would-be native Americans barely able to manage the accent. But a cast there is however, with cutscenes and a story too that - although not particular exciting - perfectly enforces the atmosphere of being a Canadian lumberjack on the frontier of a dangerous wildernesses. The mythology of werewolves and Canadian folklore is handled with careful respect and soon you'll be facing creatures from both British Canadian Christian fables and Native American Folklore. Even items are carefully described for their history in logging and Canadian history. I don't even mind the completely outdated method of clicking on individual buildings when going to town to buy gear. It adds to charm. The sound and music make up for a lot and once you manage to see past the outdated looks, you'll appreciate the cartoony feeling and the perfect v-shaped broom closet that is your main character.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												I didn't know what to think about this game when I started playing, it seemed kinda "meh" at first, but.. then I realized hours have passed and I was still playing... I just couldn't stop!Once you get passed the terrible looking cutscenes and the extremely campy, laughable voice acting, you'll be treated to the awesome unique style, story and gameplay that makes this game very addicting and fun to play.The difficulty will either make you hate or love this game, you have almost limitless ways of slaying your foes, dozens of traps, trinkets, pistols, rifles and melee weapons. Each enemy have its own weakness/strenghts and it's up to you each day to prepare for battle at night (where the action takes place) you really need to plan ahead to succeed, just winging it doesn't cut it.The visuals won't blow you away, at times they are actually quite painful to watch.. however, for the most part, they work, they fit well with the unique style of the game, in the end I was actually enjoying the "old timey' look, still not sure what happened with the cutscenese tho, they seems to be rendered at sub HD resolutions...Overall, it was a surprise hit and I'm looking forward to "Part 2" If your looking for something different, you just might be surprised like I was, check it out, you never know :D7/10

												A massively under-rated game. I would recommend this game to anyone! I picked it up in a sale and haven't regretted it. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Very rarely do I write reviews for games but I felt this one deserved it. This game takes several elements from my favorite genres (RPGs, Strategy, Action/Adventure) and puts them all into one very well-done package. The decisions you make when leveling and planning your strategies are tough and have real consequences on the outcome of the game. Often times you are on your toes trying to get from one place to another on the map and the sense of urgency during the nights you are trying to survive is persistent and effective. The story was very interesting and keep me playing. I almost beat this game in one sitting to find out what was happening. It is a unique and dark story line set in the late 1850s and the time period and setting really add to the story being told. Gameplay elements are good, there are a few small bugs but nothing that really got in my way of enjoying the game. The graphics are simple but they work-it is an indie game but deserves way more attention. There are hand-drawn cutscenes from time to time that add to the experience. You will hear several people talk about the music in this game and let me say they are not wrong in stating it is excellent. I loved it so much I tracked down the artists online and will be buying the albums. They are all French so it was a bit of a hunt but the music is so good it didn't bother me. I hope to see a sequel to this at some point. I would highly recommend this game, especially when on sale.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												A game that surprised me in more than one way. With a good story, nice atmosphere , offering a lot of ways to survive each night and adding a RPG skill tree for your character to evolve when enough experience is accumulated, Sang-Froid Tales of Werewolves was indeed a worthwhile experience. I took my time with this game, and played with Jack (higher difficulty) and it proved to be challenging. You must be careful how you spend your action points each day and your money, so planning is the key action here. Taking on the werewolves, wolves, windigos, fire demons on your own without traps is not reccomended. If you want something quite interesting to play that will keep your mind busy with setting traps as well as being cunning in combat, this is the game for you. (you also get bonus points on enjoying this game if you like werewolves, wolves in particular!! )

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Sang-Froid is a good game with a unique take on the classic tower defence genre. You still have towers and traps. You still defend. However, the majority of your traps require you, the player, to operate them. So, the gameplay is shifted to focus on player mobility and positioning as opposed to statically looking at a top down map. The game is also soaked in theme and has a good story to go with it.My only two complaints are the length (I felt i was just getting into the game when it ended) and that I personally don't care for the artistic style of the in game cut scenes. The intro cut scene (shown above in the trailer) is supurbly done. Unfortunately, for most of the game the cut scenes are two characters with a static background (example above in the screen shots for the game). It's OK... but dynamic cut scenes would have been far better.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												An excellent RPG/Tower Defense hybrid. While I find that many Tower Defense games that put you into the action become to frenetic and less tactical, Sang-Froid gives a good balance of personal action and methodical strategy. The gameplay elements built on top of the tower defense elements (enemy fear, sound, wind) provide interesting strategy choices as well as really helping the thematic feel of the game.All in all it's really well done, fits together, and is a lot of fun, I'd definitely recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												Rating: 7/10Overview: Third Person, Tower DefenseSimilar Games: Orcs must Die, Iron BrigadeThe Good:+ This games focus is more about strategy and tactics. Unlike other tower defense games that throw tons of enemies at you, SangFroid gives you less enemies but makes them more powerful. In addition, the traps you place can only be used once per level making placement even more important. + Lots of different traps that fit specific purposes, some must be activated manually making placement even more important. + Lots of different weapons and accessories for combat+ Completing levels grants you experience to upgrade skills and traps.  + The game does a good job of slowly introducing new enemies and traps so you never feel overwhelmed. Has a good tutorial that explains many of the games mechanics. + soundtrackThe Average:Melee and range combat feels lackluster. The Bad:- The story deals with supernatural elements but awful dialogue and lackluster voice acting bring the entire presentation down. You could easily skip all the cutscenes and still enjoy the game - The game is poorly optimized. Even with a computer that well exceeds the max requirements, the game had terrible frame rates. Setting a lot of the graphical option to low helped fix the problem.- long loading time when first starting game- For a game in this genre, this game is missing a lot of modes that are practically standard in other tower defense games. For starters, you cannot replay a level without losing all your save progress after that point. After completing the game there is very little reason to go back and play the game other than hunting for achievements. ConclusionA great take on the tower defense genre and has a lot of potential. I would love to see a sequel that improves a lot of its flaws.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Seems like a real gem of an indie game. Personality and care in design seem to be dripping off it, despite some meh voice acting (to be expected in the indie scene though). Too bad it refuses to run in full screen, no matter how much I play with the graphical settings of both the game and my computer. The icons render too itty bitty to read, and the game is essentially unplayable. This is a apparently a problem with my monitor, in the sense that my monitor uses tech that is more advanced than what the game supports. But even when I scale my monitor's resolution down to 1024x768 and adjust the game's settings to match it, the game window just gets smaller and smaller. I get the best results keeping the monitor at 3200x1800 and running the game at 1900x1080, but even then it still takes up just a third of the screen. Probably a problem unique to my particular monitor, but unfortunate that I don't get to enjoy the game as intended, and I just wanted to put that out there as a potential warning, even if it is an unlikely one. The game still gets a recommendation on spirit alone.

												All aspects of the game are wonderful, made with thoughtful complexity. Strategic phase where/when you place traps, simple skill tree and some various items that nevertheless push character in the direction of your prefered playstyle, and combat phase where your strategic planning unfold, all are beautifully interwoven into great game of quite unique genre.And what makes you constantly motivated throughout the game are new strategic elements that evolve step by step till the end. Its a shame that such a great game got so untalented actors and dialog writer.Another downside of the game is that it doesnt have other play mode than the story play mode which is quite short.If you like making strategic solutions, timed 3rd person hack and slash alike action with a scent of rpg then this is the game you will enjoy.9/10

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												I have not played this game in awhile, but I wanted to give a review in light of the possibility of increasing its visibility via Steam nominations.  I have played no other games in this genre, but many compare it to the Orcs Must Die series.  This game combines elements of FPS, tower defense, and RPG wrapped in a beautiful package inspired by obscure history and folklore.  Combining Quebecois and indigenous folkloric elements in a mid-nineteenth century milieu, there is no setting like it.  This is very refreshing in a culture industry where "generic high fantasy" is now ubiquitous and passe, often falling back on Tolkien without understanding what makes his oeuvre magisterial and immortal.  Some have criticized the voice acting for a lack of polish, but it has a heartfelt community theater style that charms, entertains, and fits this project.  The stakes and tension in the story grow steadily to fever pitch, and the cliffhanger left me wanting more immediately.  There are several mechanics and ways to play, so you can experiment with different styles-guns, potions, traps, magic-in each playthrough.  The tight time and resource management in some missions and the overall arc heightened the sense of excitement and urgency and the need to engineer a perfect defensive strategy.  I preordered it for $13.49 years ago and still believe it would be worthwhile at even twice the price.  It is just that fun and unique.  The only real criticism I have is that the game is not well optimized and is slow to load initially, but I think it is a triumph when considering the time and resources available to such a small team.I very much hope more attention and sales give the developers the wherewithal to forge ahead and make the sequel this game so richly deserves.
