number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												I expected to like Sang-Froid more than I did. It's stylish and the music is great and I enjoyed the low-tech theme and Quebecois flavor. And I can overlook the bad voice acting. The visauls were good enough; strategy games are rarely about animations and cutscenes anyway. But every strategy game lives and dies by its gameplay, and I this is where I really felt let down by Sang-Froid. Combat felt repetitious, and I found it frustrating that traps didn't always catch critters when their paths went directly over the traps. It felt less like strategy and more like fighting a finnicky game by playing the encounters over and over with minor adjustments.Most frustrating, though, was the amount if time it took between scenarios. There's so much story and not enough gameplay. and the gameplay didn't really live up to the wait, for me.Still though, Sang-Froid is stylish in spades! I wish more games took thematic chances like this, and it's a worthy entry in a busy Indie scene.Did I enjoy Sang Froid enough to finish it? No. Do I think that you should try it and decide for yourself? Yes!I'm looking forward to future entries from Artifice Studio.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I am absolutely amazed by the love of detail in this game. The music, the entire artwork with the interfaces and such, it is just incredible. Also the story is well written and the skill tree gives room for different playstyles. Sure, the graphics could be better and combat could feel a little more smooth, but it is not supposed to be a DmC or anything like that. It is a rather strategic game, that favors resource management even in combat. Another thing I want to point out is the amount of time they put into explaining everything with ingame tutorial videos, you will never feel like you missed something. This game is highly recommended to anyone that wants something out of the box, I love it!

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Brilliant concept, I enjoy how this game addresses how one could face off against multiple opponents through the use of intimidation. However, I do not recommend you get this game because the execution of this one great idea is poor and is not focused upon. Most of the time you will be running between control points babysitting them.Really wanted more from this gameplay, very sad. Oh and the rest of the game (cinematics, RPG elements) is laughable. To the creators I'd say fantastic job on trying to do something new, I never found a bug or a readily abusable exploit. A game I would love is in here but too much running from point A to point B to guard buildings made of wet tissue paper.

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												Sang-froid is a great game, in concept! The translation of the idea into a videogame is also done well, mechanics-wise. The big problem, for me, is how unpolished and frustrating the execution has been, especially for a 15€ game.The game feels dated in almost every respect. Graphics, story-telling, how the combat and guns work, transitions, item system, etc. etc. Everything is very imperfect and takes way more time than it should.I don't want to make a full blown review, so I'll try to very briefly state the most glaring problems.I've played the game twice. Once on Easy Mode, once on Hard Mode. Easy Mode was very uninteresting. Combat over strategy. Hard Mode was infuriating, since, while strategy was the focus, the combat was still very much required to a great degree, while your character was clearly very underpowered. As a result, almost every mission required multiple tries, even after I had the strategy laid and should have worked. I completely ignored the story and all of the other aspects aside from mechanics in the second playthrough.Why? Because it's terrible. Honestly. The story is fairly cool, especially since I do like fairy-tale and folk stories, in general. The problem is how the story is delivered. It's... mind boggling to me. The story is told exclusively through "cutscenes" that are merely characters talking to one another. Nothing fancy. The problems are: the writing isn't good, coupled with horrible voice-acting. I don't think the actors were in the same room at all. Each line feels completely disconnected from the situation at hand, and the tone is completely off. It just doesn't deliver.Then, there's the fact that, visually, they use some pretty bad 3D models, just because. The animations aren't all that great either. Nothing justifies the choice for these "cutscenes". A simple 2D conversation, with little animation and no voice-acting could have been much more polished without half of the work. Not to mention that this had nothing to do with the game. Yet, it's one of the main elements of the product, and it sticks out like a sore thumb.It's really, really, bad. I don't understand this choice at all. I could understand a sub-par execution, if it was a new idea, or something. This brings nothing new, nothing impressive. On the contrary, it's glaringly bad...The game itself, for those of you not aware, is like Orcs Must Die, although the tower and combat phases are completely separated. First, you place the traps you can. Then, you fight each wave successively, with combat. That's fine, although it can be kind of annoying when you don't know exactly what will come at you (they tell you which enemies and where, but there are nuances...) and you have no chance to fix mistakes without restarting.You'll get a plethora of different traps that you can later upgrade, but some of them are mostly useless or situational.Still, they fit the setting, and some combinations were fun to use.You can also buy potions and weapons in the town. Potions are useless, except from the health ones. The others are burnt money, unless you're on the last missions. Why? Because you barely get any money to upgrade. So, why waste it on consumables? You gain so little money that you'll take until the last few missions to be able to get a decent combination of weapons. Espcially on hard mode.Far too long.The upgrade system is cool, although you can completely lock yourself if you use your points in the wrong place. You can "undo", but only when you choose where to put them. If you "confirm",you're stuck with them.Ok, what's next?Graphically, it's a PS2 era game. If that. You can't see 7 meters in front of you, and I'm not sure if it's a design decision, or a performance choice. Then, the game suffers from fps problems when there are too many enemies active. And I have a 3.4Gz quad-core. There's no justification that I can think of, really.The combat is extremely clunky. That could be fine, since you're not supposed to use it a lot. Except... that you need to, since traps are very limited. So except lots of restarts. The game has a lock-on system that will often change targets when you least want to. There are some enemies that will go underground to heal when they're low on HP. So, you want to kill them asap.  The problem is: when there are several characters, the game may very well choose to target someone else. Well, crap...The gun suffers a similar problem with the auto-aim. It "snaps" to the closest target... sometimes. Sometimes it also seems to lag, and suddenly aims completely off, leading to a failed shot. You also take a loooong time to reload, which is cool. Bullets are also fairly expensive, so the point is to hold on to them. Which is infuriating when the game throws your aim off!Here's another thing: the game rewards you for using less traps. You can use Actions Points to cut trees, instead of placing traps. This further encourages combat, rather than strategy. Encourages the clunkiest system... And unbalances the game has a result, a bit. On Hard Mode, where you want to maximize traps, you end up getting way less money, making it even harder to upgrade, thus making the future missions even harder.There's a bit of a snowball effect, here... and not a good one.Then, there are various other problems. The interface is big and full of boxes, and still manages to miss several very important aspects... You take far too long to navigate from the stores to the village and your home. It's the clicking, but there are way too many. There's also a lot of information missing, leading to even more time wasted...There's no plain restart button that starts you exactly at the level you were in. You always have to go to the strategy screen, and then click like 3 or 4 times to confirm textboxes before you go into the level. It doesn't help that there's always a load screen between transitions. So, except 2 loading screens every time you make a mistake and want to restart. Or simply die...I realize this review is a bit toxic. I apologize for that. The game isn't terrible. The game itself, if I ignore everything else, can be fun and challenging, at times. The problem is that the game has way too many issues in too many different places, and it results in a very frustrating experience, overall.It tries to do a lot more than the game itself, but it doesn't know how. Seems like a lot of wasted work. I just can't understand the people claiming it to be a "masterpiece". In concept, it's great. Execution... not really. Orcs Must Die is a far more enjoyable game (both of them, in my opinion) and they provide more content than this, for a lower or equal price. And undoubtedly more finely tuned and polished.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Now, THIS is what I call a good game!You see, a big part of a game can be decided by it's first impression. Some games do it wrong and plaster your face with 3rd party launchers past Steam and a ton of logos.When I started Sang-Froid, I was instantly welcomed with a plain loading screen accompanied by the single best intro theme I've heard in months, if not years. Not kidding, I was actually disappointed when the game finished loading and the song got cut off, so much I actually went and found myself the full into song online.However, after the intro song + narration I was sure I had a neat game at my hands and I wasn't disappointed: Whilst the graphic and animations certainly aren't worthy of an AAA title (and there are a couple animation errors all across the game), they provide exactly the charme the intro already emitted. Overall, a really nice part of the game is it's atmosphere: You indeed feel like playing in the later colonial era, a time filled with issues of belief, mystic and tales. Except for the horrible facial models, everything the game shows and tells you feels really authentic.Of course we are here to play a game though, not check on a visua novel, so how's the gameplay?Intriguing, to say the least. The early days start out really simple. Go there, shoot that wolf, axe those other wolves some questions. Quickly you learn that any enemy group with more then two enemies means certain death if you don't fight with a brain (and an eye on your stamina gauge).But as the day progresses, so does your equipment, your character and, of course, the enemies, both in quality and number.On daytime, you get the next bit of the story and place traps and other devices. As soon as the sun falls, you run around, trigger the traps and defend up to 5 locations at once. Impossible you say? A nice challenge, I say, given the game has a really fair difficulty curve (and an additional 'difficulty setting' in form of two character, with one being clearly weaker then the other and advertised as 'hard mode').Overall, Sang-Froid is exactly the kind of great game I would wish every indie title would be.Though, there IS a little catch: The game has no replayability value. At best, you will go and play it twice, assuming you started with the easier character (I didn't, and are welcoming the difficulty. Albeit this cuts my potential playtime in half.) I'm currently 2/3rds through the game in mere 4 hours.This feels a tad short, especially if you got to consider the base 15€ price. I personally purchased it in the 90% off deal and therefore are HIGHLY pleased with the price-playtime ration.Judgement: 9/10 (Can't give it a 10, even though not gamebreaking, those animation glitches ARE annoying at times)Must-buy if on sale and on 5€ or less.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												A mythic tale of a frontier town, a farmstead, two brothers and a cursed sister, a priest, the devil and a horde of ferocious werewolves. Hell, that's a premise I wanted a piece of!Alas, Sang-Froid is a good idea that lacks in execution in just about every way. The story is nicely thought out, but let down by crude visuals and all-around shoddy voice acting. The gameplay, which promises setting traps and fighting werewolves quickly shows it's true colours, revealing a simple yet quite unfair hack'n'slasher with fickle trap-setting underneath. The combat is hard, but for all the wrong reasons: your attacks do little damage unless boosted with some booze, your gun is next to useless against most enemies, the traps only affect some enemies and not all of them and while you wail away at an enemy that hides and regenerates health faster than you can kill it, another group of enemies has burned down a critical building on the other side of the map, causing you to have to restart the night!I wanted to like Sang-Froid, but I just couldn't. It's a small-budget project trying to be a big-budget project, and the shortcomings bring it down like a house of cards. Playtime: 4+ hours (ongoing)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 5Audio: 4Story: 7Gameplay: 7Overall: 5

Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game is a real gem! It's a clever, intruiging action strategy title with a great atmosphere. It's hard to describe the game without going too much into specifics ... it's a bit in the vein of Orcs must Die, combined with some Hack'n'Slay and RPG elements. It has tactical planning and "Tower Defense" parts in it as well as challenging combat sequences. Sang-Froid is a real interesting game that stands out of the crowd by combining it's great gameplay elements with a very good, intruiging atmosphere. And it's a hard and challenging but very rewarding experience! The voice acting is not top-of-the-notch and some may not like the story but when it comes to the pure gaming experience, Sang-Froid is among the best games of this year! Must Buy!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2013
												This is a very original mashup of several different genres - a tower defender, an rpg and a TPP masher to name a few. If I had to name one game that is similiar to this one it would probably be Orcs Must Die!, but it is still very very different. Sang-Froid's setting is enough to make it stand out from the rest. The story being told takes us back to the times where the northern american settlers lived aside native indians. The player plunges into the role of one of the two O'Carroll brothers, forced to fight for the life of their ill sister and their own as well. Game consists of two distinct parts - the 'tactical' phase, taking place at dawn and the 'action' phase where our tactical plan is being put to test. Would you expect Orcs Must Die ! clone, you'd be up for a big suprise, a selection of deadly machines that chew, chop and incinerate mindless hordes of enemies is replaced by simplistic traps, overhang nets filled with stones and baits that only slow down your enemies. Most of the traps are disposed after being used and aside from a handful barely useful tools, they require to be set off manually with a painfully slow reloading rifle.Well, the game is difficult. An easy setting (represented by Joe, the burly O'Caroll brother) turns out to be nowhere near easy. On the other hand failure comes free-of-charge and you can repeat and rethink your tactics infinitely, as long as you're not satisfied with the success. There's nothing cheap about the challenge, not Borderlands 2 half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥design or numbers ridicule. It takes a bit of thought to survive each night, but it's both satisfying and rewarding once you make it.Obviously the game is not perfect. A little rough round the edges, some animations could be a tad more refined and so on - but that's nothing you wouldn't expect from an indie game coming from a very small studio. My biggest gripe is the awful voice acting which does nothing but hinders the story told. I'd glad with no va at all, in favour of the subtitles, unfortunately the option isn't there. On the other hand the folkish score is loveable and really adds to an already great package.Bottom line: buy it, these guys deserve your support. It's definitely worth it's current price-tag and getting it on sale is a no-brainer.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Sang-Froid - Tales of Werewolves combines tower defense with wilderness survival horror and a little resource management/trade, and achieves this hefty little combo with style and panache.  There are some truly original mechanics in the game, such as the "fear factor" that pits your own character's fear (or bravado) against that of the blood-hungry beasts of the night - when the werewolves pluck up enough courage, they will attack; this passing of time is represented by a meter on the HUD.  This mechanic can create some really tense moments as you frantically struggle to reload your flintlock rifle, or try to get away to a well booby-trapped spot on the farm before the hairy hordes close in for the kill.  From historically accurate weapons and equipment to an easy to access resource management element, there is plenty to keep the player engrossed in many hours of werewolf bashing.  Oh, and did I mention this game has possibly one of the best (and most fitting) soundtracks I've heard?  Great fun, and at the time of posting this review a great price too.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												A really great game, its a really entertaining mash up of RPG, action, adventure, strategy. The music is a really good plus for me, really engaging folk music that fits really well with the feel of the game and I found myself bobbing along and becoming more immersed in the game everytime it came on.I'm a few hours in at the moment and its starting to get hard, and if I wanted I could make it even harder by choosing the other brother to play the story with, which by the way is really interesting as well. There are a few random moments where you think really? that just happened to happen? and some of the voice acting/cutscene animations are pretty bad but for me it doesnt take away from the gameplay at all. Its a very immersive game and will keep you coming back to play the next level. I hope there is significant amount of content ahead of me in terms of playtime and levels but even if not I still recommend it.Give it a try, it even has a demo, you don't want to miss out.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Amazing game, simply put.It is an old school tactics game. Having to plan ahead is what makes this game so amazing.There are hard choices to make, expensive weapons for example. There is no ultimate weapon for any enemy. Same goes for traps. You will have to really think it over which enemies you want to kill first and which ones you want to delay for example.So if you like tactis, ressource management with a bit 3rd person combat, you will find your perfect match in this game.This is nothing like those "new school" tactic games made for console players. This game redefines tactical games, and it was about damn time!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Reading negative reviews,people seem to be comparing it with Orcs must Die and and condemning the lack of freedom. But that's exactly what appealed to me! Mind you ,i played with Jack on the first run(basically,hardest mode),and finding that perfect combination of traps,your combat presence,and sequence in which you deal with multiple waves was the best feeling(loved the zipline towers,allowed for more challenging maps).The "fear" mechanic brings much needed order and planning into combat,minimizing risk of botching a good run if you prepared beforehand.Don't forget that Orc Mus Die also have its "perfect builds",which you tend to fall back into and raise the tedium aspect.Overall, i recommend this for "perfectionist" type of players,who love tower defense genre,but just about ready to play more experimental mix. Don't worry, combat here is  more tactical then it tends to be in these types of games(Sanctum,OMD).PS:You mind need to work a bit on your aim though,reload times are crippling early on.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												Ultimately this game was well thought, and put together. Although if they had just put some extra time to fix the minor things could have been much better. When I first start the game, it takes about 1-2 minutes to get past the load screen when I have 200 fps. Now, I'd be more okay with sitting in a load screen for 1-2 minutes if there was actually something going on, or had better music. It plays the same sound track that is about 20-30 seconds long on loop till you get past the load screen. Then you jump straight into a cut scene that doesn't make much sense till you play the more of the game. Although if you don't take the time to play the game you won't find out why they threw a random cut scene in your face. Warning, when werewolves come they're loud as all hell can get. I have my setting on low for sound effects and music and my computer volume at 5 and it sounds as if there was a actual wolf howling in my ear. That♥♥♥♥♥♥is loud. You get about 2 charaters that you can pick from, either are large burly man or a smaller man. They show a girl, that at first I thought you could play, but when I hovered over her, I couldn't. Now, I haven't played very much of the game, so maybe later in the game you can play the charater later on. Cut scenes from what I have seen I am not pleased with. I hear 2 different pitches from just being in a regular game, to a cut scene the voice can have a different pitch or almost sound completely different. From seeing the first cut scene within the first few seconds I expected lips to move at least. If you look close enough, sure you can see 100 pixels move, but it doesn't look like a lip is actually move, but just glitching. They show other larger things moving in the cut scene, but what I couldn't understand is not a simple lip movement? There was a very small story from what I was getting at. The usual werewolves are destroying farms etc. So, I would strongly reccomend against buying this game for the story line, because it's mainly a tower defense game.  The actual gameplay it's self is very well put together. Will I be playing more of this game, probably. The way they did the traps, was some what acurate, but well thought for the game, so that wolves don't just go "HAH ♥♥♥♥ YOUR TRAP". They also didn't make the traps insanly over powered. Now, there are different leveled wolves which makes the game more interesting and makes you think more about how to place things, because if you place things in then wrong spot you can lose the night. The game is pretty much a 3rd Person, Strategy, Tower Defense game. I would reccomend the game to those who enjoy games that you need to think, and just run around in cirlces in. Like I said the game was well put together, and unique for how they did this.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Amazing.Love the different aspects of theis game, the developers realy make you think about how you are going to plan the traps for the night to give you an edge over the monsters.And i love the fact that they make you pay dearly if you have misplaced a trap or a bait and you will have to mak do with your axe.Also making the main character waeker than the enimies is a great idea it realy makes you think that if you have to use hand to hand combat (or in this instance, axe to claw) you have to use every thing you can to get an advantag, from using your musket, making an attmept with your axe, or even luring your enemies to a trap that hasent been used. Also I love that you realy have to use anything to put distance between an army of werewolves and yourself and bonfires are the best to do so, because if you think that if just yur axe will get you through the night your are wrong.And having the buildins to protect is a great idea it makes the night less about making sure that the character lives and more about making sure the builds survive.All in all "Sang Froid Tales Of Werewolves" one of the best stratagies/action games I have ever played.Hope they release a sequal, remeber this is tome 1.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												I am so pleased that I got this game greenlit, it's a amazing game. You play as one of the O'caroll brothers who ends up defending their sister from werewolves. In this game, the story of these werewolves and wolves is that they are under the control of the devil. Werewolves are created from souls of sinners that are expelled as they sleep and then merge into a wolf, creating the humanoid wolves you fight, but there are a range of other creatures to fight which have their own weaknesses and strengths in reguards to how traps effect them, in lures work and what might do more damage.The story is very good and the switching between axes (holy for one type, silver for others) and preparing traps makes the stategy all the more interesting. There are also three types of bullets. normal, holy and silver which have their uses, however the rifles they use are old fashioned musket rifles so you will need to make sure that one shot counts and kills whatever you are shooting at. The only things that let it down is it suffers from Brutal Legend's idea of replaying missions where if you do it, you erase all data of the missions you completed after that and so you can potentially farm xp or cash to help you in the final battle or just to improve yourself in the events, however unlike Brutal Legend you are given a clear warning before doing this. Buy this as soon as possible, I highly recommend it!

Posted: October 12, 2014
												This game was one of the first games I saw on greenlight. The premise looked interesting, but I wasn't sure how well it would work. After playing the game though, I cannot recommend the game enough. Having to tactically place and manage traps was surprisingly engaging. Fine tuning a trap layout after a failed night was rewarding. The melee combat isn't perfect, and it was designed to be that way. Enemies are threatening in combat, which means you have to balance your stamina, your attacks, and your fear level. It all boils down to an absolute gem, with an charming aesthetic, and an absolutely lovely soundtrack.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												This game is similar to a tower defense-style game such as Sanctum, where you place towers but are also controlling your character in third person from the battlefield. You don't actually place towers though, you place traps in an attempt to stop werewolves and other creatures of the night. Every day begins with you setting up your traps in a bird's eye view style. This leads to an interesting metagame where some traps cost AP (action points), but also money. It becomes difficult to balance setting up enough traps to win, while saving enough money and AP(which can be converted to money) to get better gear so later levels are easier. It's really fun trying to find the most cost-effective way in which to win a night. Also, your character fights with an axe and a musket.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is a really interesting game. As an action tower defense game you can't avoid comparing Sang-Froid to Orcs Must Die. However, these games are very different in gameplay and layout. In Sang-Froid you prepare all your traps before starting the level in contrast to OMD where you start the level and then place traps. In that manner Sang-Froid is a little more slow paced and not quite hectic as OMD, but enough with the comparison. Let's focus on Sang-Froid alone.The story isn't the strongest side of Sang-Froid and the same could be said about the voice acting and cut-scenes. On the contrary the music is really great and it's a perfect fit for the game. The surroundings and the environment also suits this game nicely. I really like the cold, snowy lumberjack theme. The game evolves around one single map which you play every mission. It could let you to believe it would get boring quickly, but the map changes enough along with the objectives that it doesn't feel boring. The traps offer a good variety of different killing possibilities. You can upgrade weapons and traps for the fur you sell after killing wolves or werewolves. You could also buy potions and other useful item between each level.What I would like to have seen is that when you play the game the second time with the other brother you know all traps, how the map works etc. but you have to listen to how to use the traps again. It would have been nice to have these things unlocked after you beat the game once. Also, a co-op mode would have been a nice feature. Perhaps in a sequel? Or as the story in this game turn out, a prequel would be more fitting...All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and it was well worth the money.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												You'll not find a decent story here.Visual style is rather unappealing.Replayability is about as low as any game gets.So "Why am I recommending this game?" you ask?I'm recommending it for the sake of the gameplay.In a way this game reminds me of the original witcher game. That is because, like there, you deal with enemies posing real threat by preparing in advance. Each enemy has it's own quirks, strenghts, and weaknesses, and while they are not as tough as the videos make them look, they do pose enought threat to make you want to adapt to those strengths and weaknesses.What makes the game hardly replayable is the fact that it's a lot more learning curve dependant than an average game. So for example, you'll get your fun from figureing out the way to get 5 enemies with one spike trap, but once you know how it's done there's nothing notably satisfying about that any more.The story and visual style also remind me of the original witcher somewhat. That is because, like there, they are not "hollywoodish", which is a compliment in itself, if you ask me. Noting else good to say about them though - the game is visually poor and pale. And the story is bad in more ways than one... Rarely have I seen a story that's both religious enough to irritate atheists, occult/blasphemous enough to irritate monotheists, plain enough to bore the fans of the mystic themes, and bland enough not to impress a casual reader. I seriously can't imagine what they were thinking while making a game with that story...That said, the games are meant to be played, not read or watched or heard (btw, the soundtrack here is great, if you ask me), and this game is worth playing.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												In my opinion it is a gem in the sewers of clones stininking up the market. A granted the cutsences are about as entertaining as a puppet show. But you once you look past that it is a rock solid tower defence. It can get edgy when you know one missed shot on a rockfall could mean the diffrence between wolf kababs and getting mauled to the respawn. I played the less durable of the two brothers for a hardy game experince and don't regret it.Pro: Truely unique tower defence. Nothing feels more fufilling then having everything go as planed. Or on edge when things fall apart. In relaton to lining up the crosshairs and clicking M1 on a generic FPS with helth reguvination.Pro: Uniqe game mechanics. Not wanting to spoil to much, but lets just say I wish I could wash the wolf blood off when the wind picks up.Pro: Imersive as I said nothing is more on edge when a single shot gone wrong or a trap not going as planed ruin the plan set. Or hacking your way out of a 6 wearwolf choir when you realize you forgot the bait.Pro: Beautyful music and great audio quality.Con: Puppeter cuttsences. And bland perdictable dialog. Could be improved using accents or slang from the era.Con: Combat can get sticky even with full fatige. Hitboxes can get hit and miss. Comparing the hitbox registration to TF2 or Day of DoD. though it is slightly better.Con: Not much replay value its just the story line. No sandbox, endurence, multiplayer, or much customization. Granted the game is emersive I just don't have the urge to play it again. Still I got 10-12 hours out of the game. So did I have as much fun as going to the movie theator or more fun then the amout of ice cream sandwiches? That awnser is yes.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												Sweet merciful heavens is this game weird.  And I love it.  Sang Froid is a strange beast.  I know it won't be for everyone, but for me, it was pure bliss.  The story is actually fairly unique, taking a different spin on the werewolf lore than the usual and throwing in some native american lore for good measure.  While it is a bit campy, it's fun and one of the most Canadian games in existence.  It has great flavor and atmosphere.But how is the combat?  In a word, clunky.  The game mixes setting traps, some automatic and some you have to trigger, alongside fighting in third person.  The traps are very cool, but the fighting itself is a bit awkward to get around, whether it's swinging your axe or aiming your gun.  However, if you can get past that, it is a ton of fun.  There are some ingenious mechanics, such as having to take into account how your scent is carried on the wind, the long load times of a musket rifle, and how afraid your enemies are of you.  This, combined with setting traps and planning your battles in the day, and actually fighting at night, makes for an addictive experience.Comes highly recommended.  I played through both campaigns and loved each of them.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												I was excited from the first time i saw the info on this game. "Tower defense? Third Person Brawling? Beards? Werewolves? This is going to be awesome!"I'm the kind of person who WANTS to like every game he plays. Heck, I even made myself like Two Worlds for the xbox 360...This game was a heartbreaker, though. Yeah, it had good music and nifty art, but the positivity stops there.There were more glitches in the first 20 minutes of play than you could find in any other 3 alpha-stage games combined. The combat system fell so far bad, it actually took away from the game. I play PC games quite often, even some twitch-shooters, and I have never seen lag like this. It takes roughly 2-4 seconds for any single command I make to be enacted in game.I thoroughly hope the developers will spend a little more time fixing this one. Maybe they can polish this up and turn it into an enjoyable gaming experience and have it back in our hands. Until then, I consider this game a full waste of my funds, and will not even attempt to open the file again.

number of helpful: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												The basic gameplay is pretty good but the pacing is terrible. I doubt the developers played through their own tutorial. You get a short video when a decent item description would have done the job. Rather than encouraging players to explore, the game assumes the player is a moron and tells you exactly what to do, step by step for the first 3 levels. That is in addition to the pop-up tutorials every 20 feet. If you think the gamers will be too stupid to figure out your game, maybe the solution is to make the mechanic more intuitive, not have 2 dozen videos explaining various concepts peppered in waypoints.The game does get more challenging and fun later on but the interface remains clunky. The game is plagued with interface issues: you can undo traps but not work, the hud favors artistic flare to actually providing information (health bar most guilty), you have to navigate through a half dozen buildings in town for upgrades and items, even though it could have easily all been fit into a single interface.The game lauds it's exciting and epic story. Yet aside from an awesome opening cinematic, the game chooses to tell the story in laughable animations. They are poorly dialogued, occur much too frequently and worse, doesn't inform or drive gameplay at all. They break up the pacing of the game and most of the characters are one dimensional. Instead of a handful (yes more than 1) of animations every level, a cinematic every 5 would have been amazing.I bought Sangfroid expecting an exciting indie game with fresh gameplay. The gameplay mechanics are pretty interesting, maybe even enough so to be called unique and exciting. But the rest of the game feels just like the bloated mess out of major studios. If this is an indie game, it most certainly doesn't feel like one. Gameplay was the coin spent to purchase all the frills in the game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Not a particularly good game...  The gameplay consists of the player fending off several waves of werewolves and other creatures sent each level.  Most of the strategy in the game involves preparing traps and other items to assist the player before each "night".  To help with this the number, location, and targets of each enemy and when they appear are given before each level.  If all else fails the player can try to kill anyenemy directly with an axe or rifle.  The ability to prepare the field before each level makes the game interesting, especially as most traps and items are readily avialable for the player and there's a wide variety to choose from.  Unfortunately, most traps are difficult to use as they require careful enemy positioning that quickly becomes problematic to impossible as the number and variety of enemies increase in each level.  As enemies are relatively easy to kill in melee combat, as your character is somehow able to dodge like Kratos and can easily stun lock most enemies, I gave up on using traps altogether, in some levels, and just ran around beating everything into submission.  Oh there is a story, but it's not worth talking about.  Nonsensical plot with bad voice acting throughout.   Pro's:- Wide variety of traps and enough info provided to adequately plan against enemy attacks- Upgrade system- Fluid combat systemCon's:- Voice acting- Storyline makes less sense the more you think about it- Repititve level design- Traps poorly balanced (some way overpowered, while others are Ineffective or overly difficult to activate)- Too easy to kill most enemies in melee combatOverall I'd give this game a 6/10.  Best to save your money for something better.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Let me start this off by saying that I REALLY wanted to enjoy this game; Sang Froid features an original and interesting idea, but is marred by plain out lazy execution.The first serious problem you will encounter in this game is the terrible pacing. It starts you off in a child-like hand holding tutorial which you must suffer through. The tutorial is explained by an older gentleman in segmented videos. This format leaves absolutely no room for learning or experimentation. The hand holding doesn't stop with the tutorial vidoes either; through out the game you are constantly bombarded by annoying pop ups containing tips.Another problem, although small, and perhaps unimportant to some, is the poor voice acting, which is painfully apparent. This is honestly some of the worst voice acting I've ever encountered. The acting and dialogue feels incredibly forced and not fluid at all. This lack of fluidity also applies to the cutscenes and animations. The combination of all this makes it impossible for me to be invested in the story.I was expecting the saving grace for this game to be the combat, unforunately, the combat is actually shallow and uneventful. With the assisted aiming and large packs of enemies, fighting foes turns into a mouse clicking fest in which you will find yourself monotonously smashing the attack button. There is a "fear" mechanic which is meant to play in with the stamina feature. Enemies have a "fear" meter that slowly builds. Upon reaching a certain point of fear, the animal will then attack. In the time spent waiting for an animal's fear to rise to an attacking point, you'll have time to reload your rifle and let your stamina regenerate. So by the time the enemy comes to attack, you're already fully loaded and prepared, which really dictates the pace of fighting into an almost turn based setting. I have no qualms with the day time planning strategizing portion of the combat.When you combine all these problems with the unintersting and sporadic story, you feel left with a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥game with poor atmosphere.Ultimately, I can only reccomend this game to children, or perhaps even first time gamers who need generous doses of help and guiding.

Posted: August 21, 2016
												I'm not trying to bash indie games. I am very glad independent companies are able to create and publish their work and i will support all the ones that are worth it. This one is not.The 3D art is ok. The 2D art - dear god, I can draw better and I don't even have an art degree.The voice acting - *sigh* i feel bad for complaining, i know not everyone has the budget for real actors, but you know how other developers get away with this? By not having voiced dialog. I would rather have to read than listen to what sounds like an awkward highschool kid trying to act and miserably failing.Game mechanics - there are some interesting ideas i guess. But it was so limited - the skills, the traps, everything felt not polished enough, not evolved enough. This is a game that could use a big name company makeover, because without it - it's just a sophomore-year video-game class project.The game was pretty challenging at times too, but overall it just felt like a chore trying to finish it.

												Not as much fun as I thought it could be.Before the game actually starts, you get the chance to buy items or build traps on the map. When the night starts you try to lure enemies into the traps or you kill them yourself.The core idea of this game is promising, but controls are not very smooth and the number of traps or options is pretty limited which makes the game repetive and easy. So there is not much strategy involved.Usually, that alone would not be enough for me writing a negative review, because it all depends on your taste. The main reason why I would not recommend this game is the loading screen bug.When you start the game you may be caught in a endless loading screen. Finally, when you manage to get to the main screen, you may not get any Steam achievements later, if you Alt + Tab during the loading screen before. This is kinda bothersome, especially if the loading takes considerably longer than most games. So if you want to get achievements, you are forced to watch LOADING...

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												So, this is a game that seriously confused me. When I first saw it, I wasn't sure if it was an action-style RPG, or what it was, but when I actually PLAYED it, the horrible truth dawned on me... it's a focking tower defence game! Now, I'm no stranger to the TD-genre, both the armchair general type where you just place towers/turrets/whatever down on a map to stop/kill the incoming enemies (Defence Grid or Plants VS Zombies), and the "up close and personal" kind where you actually get to do some runnin' 'n' gunnin' yourself (Orcs Must Die! and Sanctum), but Sang-Froid isn't really either. Taking enemies on in a head-to-head fight is to say the bloody least STU-PID unless they're just basic wolves and you're playing as Jos, AND WHY WOULDN'T YOU, SINCE HE'S APPARENTLY BETTER THAN WEAK-MODE JAQ IN EVERY SINGLE WAY!!! Anyway, where was I... oh, yeah. Sang-Froid's gameplay. It's an interesting enough concept, but the execution is like a wobbly, woinky... something. Basically, it's flawed as all FOCK! The music isn't BAD, but it's nowhere near GOOD either, and the cutscenes honestly look like they were made with cardboard cut-outs of the various characters, i.e. they're basically shïte. So, it all boils down to the final number. The show-ender. The, uh... yeah, whatever. I'm out of analogies. Here's the score. 4.7/10

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												I really want to like this game as the presentation and story are really great and want to draw me in but unfortunately the poor pacing and slow trial and error gameplay really shatter my interest in this title.The UI, the way the story is told and the writing itself is very cozy. It really makes an interesting universe until you actually do start controlling your chosen character then it really goes down hill. Gameplay comes down to building defenses and then defending the buildings your supposed to. Early on this isn't so bad until you start hitting 3 or more buildings where you have to defend them all and they are all vastly far from eachother and in the event of one being destroyed you lose so you end up having to do a bit of multi tasking in order to keep everything together and this can require trial and error as you figure out what will work and what wont for each mission. The combat though is very floaty and dousn't feel very solid. If I didn't know better I would think you weren't actually supposed to go into direct combat with enemies since it feels very poor when compared to the presentation quality of the rest of the game. Its clunky and at times it can be difficult to hit enemies with your melee attack and in the process get hit yourself. Some of the aspects like fear and rage are very interesting but unfortunately managing these aspects on top of the combat on top of defending your buildings isn't really fun after a time as you battle with the clunkiness while trying to do everything before one of your buildings die. The pacing really becomes a problem at the point where the game becomes challenging as it gets so slow that the high points are not high enough to actually make it worth it.So maybe I will someday play more of Sang Froid but for now I really have no impetus to play more of it and would rather just like to see the story play out but not enough to actually beat the game.Also for as basic as the graphics are its very poorly optimized. Many basic video settings such as windowed mode are not supported either. So once you start peeling back the facade the lack of structure shows. As an analogy I think that fits this game at where I am in it.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Sang-Froid is a hybrid 3rd person action / tower defense game that excels at neither. In fact, both elements are constantly tripping the other up.Basic premise: You defend various buildings against monster (mostly wolves and werewolves during the night, and build/upgrade during the day. You kill monsters with both traps and your axe/musket.On the surface it's a great idea for a game. You're trapped in spooky isolated woods and during the day you have to spend your limited time choosing how to survive the coming sunset.Why it fails is because the 3rd person movement and controls are so sluggish, the map is far too spread out, and the majority of the traps require you to be present in order to take effect but you can't be everywhere at once.3rd person action: super clunky melee swings and musket reloading. I realize it's not going to be as fast paced and adreniline pumping as a dedicated action game, but if it's going to be THIS clunky and boring then they should have just ditched it to make this a full on tower defense strategy game. You're not shooting huge guns like Sanctum, you're dealing with clunky axe swinging. There's a system where you have to manage the wolves' fear level; keep them afraid enough so the entire pack doesn't jump you at once. This might have been interesting in a game with better combat, but it's just frustrating because you don't have time to deal with it because your other building are all the way across the map.Overly large map: The full map (once all locations open up) is larger than most DotA maps and it takes a good 2 minutes to traverse the entire thing. It's way too slow and you have to be everywhere at once. Later on you can build ziplines to travel quicker, but then you have to sit through the slow climbing animations like it's a Zelda game, plus the ziplines cannot go through trees and the whole map in one winding forest. Since it's 3rd person, you can only see what's in sight of your character and have little idea what's happening other than some icons on the map. This is a big problem because...Non-automated traps: The majority of the traps in the game require you to be present in order to work. You must shoot ropes to drop rocks on wolves. You must light bonfires. You must man turrets. The whole point of traps should be to cover areas you can't be at. If they can't do that then what's the point and why not just make it a full on action game? There are a couple traps that theoretically take care of things when you're not there, but they're unreliable. You can lay down flaming trenches that monsters can't cross, but it's very hard to tell if the trench is completely blocking off a path or if there's one tiny pixel you missed that monsters can pass through, derailing your entire plan and forcing you to start over. Likewise with lethal traps. You can place 3 lethal traps at a chokepoint and sometimes all the monsters will run into them, sometimes none. It's totally random which is the opposite of what a good tower defense game should be.The story: The devil is summoning monsters to attack you. That's the entire story, but they drag it out with non-animated, horribly acted, boring cutscene after cutscene.There was a kernal of a good game idea buried in here somewhere. If they were going to make so many traps reliant on you being present, they should have turned it into primarily an action game. If the action was going to suck so much they should have turned it into a pure strategy game. In trying to do both they compromised each other.

number of helpful: 18 of 40 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Pre-summary:  Get "Orcs Must Die" instead.The folk music in this is really great, it's moody and well utilized to draw you in right from the start.  The music is certainly the best part of the game.  I'll give a nod to the interesting art design as well, but the execution is pretty sub-par.The game itself is a mashup of tower defense and third person brawler/shooter, with the map you're defending expanding after each round as you unlock new tools and resources.  There's promise there, but it's poorly delivered on and ultimately provides a choppy and inconsistant experience.The plot is... bad.  It's bad.  It's reall, really, so very bad.  It seems promising at the start, but by the second or third round it's almost bad enough to be ironically entertaining.  The devil is particularly amusing, while the depiction of the natives actually verges on upsetting.There are better games out there that deliver on this mechanical concept more fluidly, and there are better stories about werewolves in frontier times.  But it's too bad the sound track isn't available as a seperate purchase.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2013
												Awesome game.  Unique concept. Interesting upgrades and leveling to keep you addicted.  Atmosphere is top notch.  I loved the look of the land as it evolved, just felt right.  My favorite part of the game had to be "day time" or "set up time".  I really enjoyed placing fire walls to lead the enemy onto the path I wanted them to go, hitting all the traps I intended. Just a piece of advice though, don't go spending all your money or Action Points during set up, as the best weapons will cost a lot later on, making it a good idea to budget your funds and to use the least amount of traps possible.The only real cons I see in this game are lack of co-op and little replay value once you beat it, other than trying the harder difficulty.Highly recommended and the devs are currently looking at some cool ideas for the sequel, or 2nd tome if you will.  And some of those features, like co-op, sound really great so please support this so we can play more games from these devs.  I'll be keeping my eyes on these guys, they have legitimate talent.

content:
Posted: March 11
												Great atmosphere, terrible gameplay mechanics.I love the setting the game takes place in, sort of a dark fairytale world that is reminiscent of Ichabod Crane and the Headless Horsemen story, only with werewolves...and the devil.Unfortunately, it has a terribly long and boring tutorial system that constantly interrupts the game to (over)explain relatively simple mechanics. (Like almost every mobile game does nowadays)  Once you get through those, you are thrust into a very hectic level without a real sense of where enemies are going to be coming from, or in what order, so you have no idea, really, where to put your traps until it actually runs through the scenario once.  I really hate trial and error gameplay, and this game is particularly unforgiving to the unprepared.  If you don't have the right traps in the right place, heaven forbid you could take on the enemies effectively with your trusty rifle.  NO, you are going to die, and then restart the level.With the awkward controls and trial and error gameplay, I cannot recommend this game.

If you want to try it, wait for it to be on sale for dirt cheap, but don't pay more than $3 for this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												A Tower Defense/Third-Person Action hybrid in the style of "Orcs Must Die!" based on Canadian lore. The game's structure is broken into pre-mission cutscene, pre-mission preparations, the actual defense of your structures on foot, and a post-mission cutscene, with no deviation in this structure. Of the twenty missions available, the first few are thinly veiled tutorials which quickly ramp up in difficulty once supernatural enemies are introduced. Unlike most games, the difficulty doesn't budge; for the most part it was a non-stop train ride through a frustratingly difficult game. I was finding myself quickly frustrated and had to restart missions many times because of accidentally hitting myself with a lethal trap, getting sidetracked defending one objective while another was being destroyed, or just dying from being overwhelmed by enemies I was unprepared to face at full health because they "dodged" a trap I set for them.While the story is good enough to push you forward and explain character actions and interactions, it really feels like it was stretched thin and simply made to build a game around. There are no sidequests, no mini-games or diversions, no non-main story character to chat with, or even any non-story or non-shops to visit while in towns. I loved the game's atmosphere and environments but much of the game feels rushed and lazy, as if the devs said "this is good enough, ship it!" The story also seemed to end abruptly and un-satisfyingly, as if the devs couldn't decide to lead into a sequel or not.I would love to see a sequel that wasn't such a barebones narrow corridor of gameplay. Simple touches, like actually being able to walk around in towns, would have added much to the atmosphere of the game. This could have been a cozy, atmospheric game with a unique spin on tower defense, but instead it feels like a quick in-betweener for a dev looking to make money for his next big project.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												As an opening to my review I would like to point out that, unlike some other publishers out there, Artifice Studio respect the Steam community and it's trader users, people who invested money in getting multiple copies of the game at a certain discounted price for trading purpose (by trading games for items we often can get our hands on other games for a fraction of the price even if already heavily discounted from other steam users who have those games) and, it would seem, they respect* that we didn't spent the money simply to see the same deal occur the next year during the anual summer/winter event and that is a good thing. *Last time Sang Froids was discounted at 90% and, right now at the time of this review during the summer event of 2015, it is 80% off and the few of us who got the game at the most advantageous price can trade with more ease compared with the games that have the same discount price showing up event after event making it difficult to make even the slightest profit from these games.You're welcomed to leave comments on this review about this subject to help us build a better trading community. On with the review now...-----------------------------------------------The game itself is pretty unique as you have hack and slash battles and first person shooter elements combined with some tower defence aspects like traps and buildings that you must defend from the invaders and lots of upgradeable abilities thrown in for good measure. The music and voice acting compliment the game ambiance in all the tongues available. The story is created in part by Bryan Perro who is famous around here in Quebec. In short you shoot werewolves after luring them under and around all sorts of traps that you acquire as you progress into the game and unravel the mystery that surrounds the town of Val-des-loups (Ancient town that no longer exist here in Quebec). Lots of fun, interesting story and good music.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Sang Froid: The Tale of a Double Whammy of Garbage. It is a TD/action game and both aspects are done in a way that suck balls. The melee combat just feels awkward and the TD aspect is boring and not done well compared to other games such as Dungeon Defenders.I realize this got a 79/100 metacritic average and I even read in the forums someone saying they have 321 hours in it but despite trying to force myself to like this I can't. The first hour of the game is about 30 minutes of tutorials/interruptions, 10 minutes of cutscenes, and 20 minutes of gameplay which is about 5-10 minutes on the planning screen/in town and 10-15 short minutes of actual gameplay. It feels like the whole game is about 50% TD/action and 50% adventure game and adventure games blow. Maybe as you play on and get the five thousand tutorials out of the way, there is more gameplay. The game just has such a bad indie game feel I couldn't stand it long enough to find out. HOW IN GOD'S NAME DID THIS GET A 79 META AVERAGE???The action game part, melee combat, is imo poorly done. Just feels awkward and clunky. Also, my guy can swing only a few times at a wolf before running out of stamina, like he smokes nine packs of cigarettes a day and has trouble breathing or something. I am out of shape badly and I could swing an axe at wolves for a good long while before I was out of breath. Combat just feels generically done. And mouse control does not feel right either because it A) uses mouse acceleration to spin the camera faster the quicker you move it and B) also does not have sensitivity matched up right on the axis'. X axis (left & right) is fine but Y axis (up & down) is too low and it makes a odd matchup and feels awful, and there are no options in the game to change it. When they can't even make the controls feel normal, that is bad news.The planning screen where you lay traps looks like crap, and all other menu screens have a crap look and feel about them. Where good games look smooth and crisp in their menu's, this one's presentation value is just sharp, dull, and ugly. That leads to the other part of the game, tower defense mechanics, which suck balls. After laying down traps and nets and stuff, I start and since they are coming from 3 different paths all over the map and the traps don't do anything whatsoever but slow them down slightly, it's like where the fk do I go first? So I pick a spot and go fight a werewolf. While I am doing that, the traps I put down slowed the others only barely so the houses are getting attacked now. The net traps I put down are hard to get anything to go underneath, especially when it says my shout isn't ready yet and I don't even think I used it yet. The wolves usually just walk passed my net trap so it is a waste and I just killed them with the clunky crap balls melee fighting.If you want a TD/action game that is properly reviewed as a good game, try Dungeon Defenders. If you want a TD/action game that all the reviewers played blindfolded, play this. I mean it honest to God boggles my mind as to how this game got a 79 metacritic average. The melee and TD portions of the game are both a nightmare compared to Dungeon Defenders.5/10, if that.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												If there's a better game out there about 19th century French-Canadians fighting werewolves, I haven't found it.But seriously, this is actually pretty fun. It's a lot like Orcs Must Die in that you're setting traps to deal with waves of werewolves and other supernatural creatures. There's a fair amount of strategy involved and you sometimes have cases where it seems like the map is impossible, but there's always a solution somewhere. The writing is pretty corny, but I enjoyed this.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game out of Montreal is very fun and satisfying to play. If you can overlook the awful cinematics and lackluster story telling, the game-play is pretty good! A Chapter or "level" consists of 2 phases: daytime strategy planning and night time combat. During the day you can visit shops in town to buy or upgrade equipment, consumables and stat modifying accessories. As well as plan your strategy to survive the coming night by setting up various traps, zip lines and build combat influencing objects like fires or shrines. Each one consumes daylight hours and sometimes money too, so it's a balance to survive as efficiently as possible in order to further fund your plan. I recommend playing on "hard" though. At night, you dash around your ever expanding forest territory to defend your friends and their homes from unholy wolf creatures. Combat system is simple and imperfect but still pretty fun. Decently designed skill tree to level through as you gain experience. Also some unique mechanics like wind direction potentially ruining your plan by giving away your scent and the degree to which your enemies fear you needing to be managed.Also worth mentioning is the soundtrack, one of it's strongest features. Found myself humming all the music and listening to what I learned was Quebec style folk music that I would have otherwise described as "Celtic."  Certainly worth the few dollars currently being asked during the sale, 15 to 30 hrs of fun strategy & third person action despite simple graphics.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Pleasantly surprised. Kill werewolves as a lumberjack in most frightening setting on earth, Canada in Winter.Picked this up in a humble bundle. Solid game that I lost a few hours into, and a very refreshing take on the action strategy genre.-You play as either a Canadian lumberjack or hermit trapper, fighting wolves and werewolves.-Canadian whisky and beer are you power ups, which is awesome.-Game mechanics are solid, and match the games theme, wind affects your scent, shooting and moving make noise, both can cause enemies to target you. -Character progression and economy are meaningfull. Seems well balanced so far.-Voice acting is a bit rough, I skipped most cutscenes, but it gets points for having a simple but charming art style in game.If you like things like orcs must die, or dungeon defenders you'll enjoy this game.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												Sang-Froid is one the of most disappointing games that I've played. I went into it thinking that it would be like Orcs Must Die but with werewolves, which sounded like a pretty awesome premise; instead, it turned out to be a clunky, dull action game with strategy and RPG overtones.The worst part of the game for me is the interface. The font used was definitely picked for style rather than legibility, making it tricky to get a quick read on your ammo count. The health bar is a strange, bifurcated heart which again is not helpful for at-a-glance info. You wield two weapons, but instead of using a toggle, weapon selection is modal. You have to hold down a key to keep the rifle out. Reloading the rifle is boosted by button mashing which is an egregiously stupid mechanic. The whole town's worth of shops could have been condensed into a single screen. The fear factor UI is painfully unintuitive but works decently once explained. I think even the developers realised how bad the UI is because the tutorial is filled with videos describing in elaborate detail how everything works. When you've gotten to that step, you need to seriously rethink your design decisions.The gameplay is where things really fell apart. It seems like most traps are one-use-only which kills the tower defence feeling for me. Because you can't rely on traps, you need to dispatch a good chunk of the enemies yourself. Unfortunately the lumberjack runs quite slowly, hits weakly and reloads his rifle in a period-correct fashion. Combat is a slow and tedious affair with the player's weakness being balanced out by the enemy's reluctance to attack. To top it off, the animations are surprisingly unsatisfying.Calling the game an epic folktale is a bit disengenuous. The writing is 90s after-school cartoon caliber and the voice acting is pretty wooden. The animations are disappointingly stilted and exacerbate the problem; using static portraits would have been a major improvement. Worst of all, it takes itself way too seriously.It's possible that the game gets significantly better after spending enough time on it. Unfortunately, there are plenty of other games that are better right off the bat.

The game is worth its price and you can spend tens of hours playing and pursuing its challenging achievements.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												Now here's a game that caught me by surprise. Sang Froid: Tales of Werewolves is Montreal-based Artifice Studio's first title, and in spite of some general shabbiness in its presentation, they've done enough things right here that I'll be keeping an eye out for their future releases.In Sang Froid, you play a pair of Canadian woodsman brothers, defending their sister (as well as the surrounding community) from nightly assaults by supernatural forces both Christian and Pagan in nature. Gameplay takes the form of an innovative and wonderfully executed combination of chop-em-up action, clever tower defense, and Rainbow Six-style tactical planning. Each day presents you with a chunk of storyline, and then lets you spend your limited daylight hours setting up traps on your property or logging at the local lumber yard for extra cash (which is spent on weapons, items, and some of the more dramatic and powerful trap-types). Thanks to your psychic sister, you know ahead of time what kinds of enemies will be attacking, where they'll come from, and what they intend to destroy; setting appropriate traps for each situation is crucial to survival, as you can only be in one place at a time, and your combat prowess is hardly a match for a single werewolf, let alone a pack of several.When night falls, the assault begins and you get to see if your defenses hold up. Armed with an axe, a rifle, and whatever consumables you've brought with you, you must do everything in your power to wipe out the assaulting units. At its simplest, you can engage opponents in melee, killing off opponents that you either hadn't set traps for or which manage to survive whatever you'd prepared. While the controls are a little wobbly at times, the combat options are innovative, simple, and very intelligent. When you aren't out busting skulls, however, your job will be to run from trap to trap, activating them at the right time to deal the most damage, or letting the enemy catch your scent and then luring them to their fiery/spiky/bouldery doom. Several enemies are very resilient to your weapon attacks, and without intelligent use of traps they can be nearly unbeatable in hand-to-hand combat. You can get around this by wielding blessed or silver weaponry, but you can only carry one axe at a time, and you can't have it both ways.I haven't had this much fun with a game in a long, long time. All the trap varieties are useful in their own way, adding interesting layers to the strategy. Plotting out the most effective and efficient layout to take out enemies is a bit intimidating at first, but quickly becomes very satisfying; there's nothing quite like knowing you've set up a fool-proof murder gauntlet and then seeing it work like a charm. Running through the woods, sneaking up on your prey as it munches on the bait you've left out; or ziplining over the forest to engage a band of demons at precisely the right moment... Each night's encounter is demanding enough to make you work for it, and all the elements involved in pulling it off are simply fun. Based purely on the gameplay, Sang Froid is an easy title to recommend.It does have a few weaknesses though. The game suffers beneath an occasionally stuttery framerate, no-budget cutscenes, fairly basic character models, a script that's difficult to take seriously, and a voice acting cast made up of amateurs (several of whom likely have English as a second language). This is more than counterbalanced by a gorgeous musical score, an unorthodox and inventive setting that drowns out the actual writing, and the stellar gameply mentioned above. If it weren't for the fact that nobody seems to know it exists, I'd say Sang Froid has all the makings of a truly great cult classic.

												Canadian Gothic Horror Tower Defense!Yes, it is as awesome as it sounds. The Devil himself has corrupted a nearby village and seeks a girl currently recovering in your cabin. Together with the few remaining townspeople, you have to defeat the armies of Wolf Packs, Werewolves and Dark Spirits that assault you during the night. Use the daylight wisely to plan your strategy and stock up on supplies, and slay the armies of Satan after nightfall.The game combines the round-based tower defense design with a very unique combat system. Use Shouts, Baits and Campfires to turn your foe's natural instincts against them! And to top it all off, it has a true Canadian angle to it. Very cool game!

Posted: January 31, 2014
												Presentation The game is divided in three forms: The cut-scenes, which are nicely represented by beautiful art in 2D, as if you were reading a book, the strategy part of the game which is represented by a map in which u have a 360 degree view of the terrain u must defend and in which u can zoom in and out and finally the action part, in which you actually put your plan into action.  The action part is cartoonish but still very enjoyable to look at and in 3D.  If you are looking for 'Crysis' graphics, look elsewhere.  It's much more art oriented.  The music is taken from canadian folklore and is quite nice to listen to.  As for the sounds (explosions, beasts roars, axe hits, guns firing,.) they are well executed and add tangibility to the game.GameplayAs mentioned above, this is a mixed game, whereas you play a tower defense game at first and after that you put your plan to execution in a 3rd view action game.  In the strategy part you are presented with a comprehensive map that tells you which creature you are going to fight, their number and their headings, i e where they will attack.  It is there that you have to put up traps to stop them from attacking buildings and thus destroying them or else you fail the scenario.  You have complete control on which traps to use, and where to use them (as long as they are unlocked from progressing in the game).  You are only limited by the in-game mechanics, i e money and action points.  The second part is as said putting your plan into execution, and this is done by pressing the 'Start the night' button in the map view.  You then have control of a lumberjack armed with an axe an a rifle and equipped with potions.  This part is rendered in 3D with a 3rd perspective aspect.  The controls are responsive and the animations are well done.  You can view in real time your traps, set them off if needed to and coming to life.  In all my gameplay, i have encountered one bug related to a specific trap, the spike trap.  Sometimes even if i was standing outside the spikes, they would hit me anyways and kill me with the other beasts standing on it.  Othe than that the gameplay is fun and sometimes even scary!ConclusionFor a 6 member studio, this game is remarkably well done.  I encountered no bugs and everything worked as described.  Depending how much time you wanna spend in the strategy map, this game should take between 10 to 20 hours to complete.  The game is not without cons, and personally i have 2.  First one is regarding the resolution.  Maybe the Devs will patch this up but for now the highest resolution is 1080P.  Second con, if they would also patch the icons in the 3D view which are not big enough with higher resolutions.  Other than that i highly recommand this game.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												You like werewolves and european folk lore? you like tower defence? you like strategy? WELL THEN! you have come to the right place! Sang-Froid offers all these things. (assuming you didn't spend it all on traps! which admittedly are a necessity if you want to succeed) All in all a very enjoyable game that i would reccomend to anyone if the things i have mentioned pique your interest!

Posted: July 18, 2015
												This is actually quite a fantastic little game.  Though it only took me roughly 4-5 hours to beat, I only played through once.   (you get to play through a second time as "the other brother", which easily doubles, if not tripples the gametime).  The first part of every night in this game is the trap set-up.  This takes a bit of thinking, and in later levels might rack your brain a bit (which is a good thing for all puzzle games).  The second part of every night is where you actually fight the werewolves and other nasties, making sure your traps function properly... and you'll know if they don't.  Admitedly, the last level (boss) frusterated me quite a bit, but after...  A dozen tries, and looking up a walktrhough I managed to get it.  I'll go ahead and spill the beans on that, to prevent frustation for any future players;  The boss (the invisible beast) can only be killed with your sister's blood on a bullet.  Assuming you make it to the boss, and you use your glasses to "see" him, AND you beat him up...  He'll get beat  up until 0 health, then he'll stand there dizzy for a matter of seconds (it's very fast).  Shoot quick with your blood-bullet while he's dizzy and at 0 health, and don't miss!  Or he'll regenerate, and you'll have to beat him up all over again!That being said (even with that minor frusteration), this game is certainly worth taking a look at, and was fun and frusterating (in a good way) - after all, if a game's no challenge, what's the point?

Posted: May 20, 2013
												A continuing evolution of the Tower Defense + OTS Combat genre, Sang-Froid strikes an amazing balance between so many different gameplay elements. A dark and well crafted story weaves the campaign together and keeps you engaged from start to finish. During the day you can examine the types of monsters that will attack during the next night and the routes they'll take. You then use your time units and money to place traps. Leftover time can be used to generate additional funds, which can be spent in the town on weapons, ammo, trinkets, and consumables. By tying money and time together, Sang-Froid forces you to make tough decisions when planning your day. It's a balance between putting the bare-minimum of traps down so you can afford upgrades without getting yourself killing the process. Combat at night is fun and tense, with good controls and a variety of monsters that need special tactics to take down. You'll find yourself juggling defending different objectives and, once again, your greatest enemy is time as you fight to clear one attack as quickly as possible so you can make it to the next objective in time. Over-all a great game on many levels, and a must-buy for anyone that enjoys Tower Defense, werewolves, or strategic OTS combat.

Posted: September 16, 2013
												Canadian Gothic Horror Tower Defense!Yes, it is as awesome as it sounds. The Devil himself has corrupted a nearby village and seeks a girl currently recovering in your cabin. Together with the few remaining townspeople, you have to defeat the armies of Wolf Packs, Werewolves and Dark Spirits that assault you during the night. Use the daylight wisely to plan your strategy and stock up on supplies, and slay the armies of Satan after nightfall.The game combines the round-based tower defense design with a very unique combat system. Use Shouts, Baits and Campfires to turn your foe's natural instincts against them! And to top it all off, it has a true Canadian angle to it. Very cool game!

Posted: January 19, 2015
												  A very nice game. While story didn't grip me, mechanics easily carry the game. It's a mix of tactical trap-based defense and real time 3rd person cmbat.  By day you set up your traps, by night you run around while the waves spawn activating certain traps, luring monsters, simply fighting or panicking because something didn't go as planned and now you have an angry werewolf on your heels.   Even real time combat requires planing and tactics. You have to manage your stamina, musket amunition and reload (it's 19 century) utilise fear through fire and  well timed attacks. Intimidated enemies give you some time to aim, reload or catch breath because getting caught in a pack of even basic wolves will hurt.  The game offers huge amounts of gameplay variation - multiple traps, trap combinations, extensive skill tree to customise your playstyle. Clear waves without moving from your front porch? Funnel enemies around 1 big exploding barrel? Drop bait to keep them occupied until you and your new silver axe can catch up? Snipe from watchtower perch? Mix and match.  Mechanics are robust, soundtrack's nice, didn't notice any glitches or bugs (wave spawning notwhistanding).I highly recommend this game for unique mix of mechanics. And being "The most canadian game ever" ©TotalBiscuit.
