Posted: April 8, 2013
												I'm not usually a fan of tower defense style games, but I actually enjoyed this game quite a bit. You fight off waves of enemies, but using traps and your own musket. There is an interesting fear mechanic, and levels are challenging while giving you an ammount of freedom in how to approach them. There are RPG elements that gave enough choices to make me feel like I was powerful while at the same time always leaving me wishing for the next level or making hard choices. Finally, with the time period, plot, and music, I enjoyed the games style. It isn't the longest or best game you will play, but I think it was well worth the $15.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												I like Sang-Froid - Tales of Werewolves for 3 reasons:1) The game play - It has a great mix between 3rd person action (smashing wolfs with axes, guns and what not); stragety in terms of placement of fire, traps and where you put your charcter & upgrading of your weapons and traps between the action.2) I love the setting - and the idea of a remote french canadian forrest town harrased by warewolves. 3) Different monsters require different tactics making you try different ways to bring them downWhat i didnt like about it:a) I found the story is a bit weak and i ended up skipping the cutsceans towards the end - i just didnt buy into the emotion behind saving your sick sister - the voice acting was fine, but it could perhaps have better script writing.b) Ended too quickly - just when i was getting into the gameplay it was all over.c) Little replayability - some variety is very much needed to make me want to play it again, such as a much harder difficulty level so i can test my skills - also some randomisation in where the monsters spawn as once you have fuigured out the tactic to a map - there is little incentivve to try another tactic.Would i recomend it? YES! and i very much hope the developers will relsease an expansion / DLC with more maps, more characters, more weapons as the gameplay is very fun and is the true highlight og the game.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												Note that this review is based on just a few hours of play; I haven't completed the game yet.Let me get this out of the way first: The cutscenes, both cinematic and in-engine, are pretty terrible and the story isn't anything to write home about.  The animation doesn't look especially good, the voice acting is sometimes questionable (on top of that, they don't pronounce things right for French Canadians which hurts my suspension of disbelief), and the writing occasionally veers into downright cringe-worthy.  I still appreciate that the cutscenes are there, since they do at least tie the missions/nights together, but I don't really enjoy them, per se.Sang-Froid is sort of a combination 3rd-person action game and tower defense strategy, and fortunately, it pulls the gameplay off reasonably well.  The strategic and tactical elements of planning out your traps and then trying to execute your plan is quite satisfying.  The game has a surprising amount of little intricate details, like how your enemies can track you via sound and scent, and how you can use an intimidation system to buy yourself some breathing room, which come together with a variety of traps, many of which require some manual management on your part, to make a game that you can actually sometimes feel cunning during.  In a testament to the developers' enemy design, the monsters actually feel fairly varied, even though their variety is in reality little more than rock-paper-scissors, and they kind of fall to the same axework.The game is at its strongest when you're planning your traps out, or rushing across the map to trip a net full of rocks just in the nick onf time.  You really get caught up in the moment, watching your plans come to fruition, or hearing the distant sound of a spike trap impaling a bunch of wolves while you're in the middle of a fight.  Unfortunately, the combat system doesn't measure up to the traps.  The ranged combat system has a far too aggressive auto-aim.  It's useful when you're trying to line up shots on circling wolves, as the rifle is meant to fire too slowly to make manual aiming feel rewarding.  But when you're trying to trigger one out of several clustered traps of nets filled with rocks, the game's inability to know which one you actually wanted to shoot as their autoaim fights each other can completely ruin a trap.  Not being able to move while reloading is frustraing, but I understand and accept the developer's decision in that regard, as it does make shooting the rifle "mean" more -- it makes using the weapon a resource beyond just the ammunition it takes, as the reload time can be a serious liability in the middle of a wave of enemies.The melee combat system feels clunky and vague.  It's more like Don't Starve than Arkham Asylum or Assassin's Creed.  While hitting enemies with your axe is rewarding, the enemy "tells" for attacks are generally not obvious enough to make the dodge system really pay off.  You'll hit a werewolf twice, then suddenly get knocked over when they attack back, seemingly without warning.  You also have little control over what you're doing beyond "swing axe," so sometimes you'll knock enemies away when you'd rather be pressing the attack.  I find myself perpetually short of stamina, which probably means I'm fighting wrong, but it still is frustrating.   The real problem though is that while the enemies behave differently in terms of traps, in combat, they all seem to fight pretty much the same; or at least your tactics for fighting are pretty much the same.  All that changes is which weapon the enemy is particularly vulnerable to, which doesn't make for especially satisfying combat.  (Then again, I get the feeling that melee combat is *supposed* to be somewhat discouraged in the game, and almost making it dull does sort of discourage it.)Each night is pretty short, but can be reasonably intense as the timing of some of your traps can be quite tight.  This gives each mission an almost bite-sized quality, so it's easy to play a couple nights in spite of a busy schedule.  It also lends itself to the "just one more" phenomenon in a way that longer missions would not.Sang-Froid has its rough spots, but I feel that the game realizes the goals it set out to achieve, and by keeping itself short and sweet it manages to emphasize its fun parts and keeps the less fun parts from becoming tedious.

Posted: January 11, 2015
												Nice indie tower defence game. Took around 20-30hrs of playtime to 100%. Much of the playtime is used in formulating a strategy for the upcoming night; determining which traps to use, where to place them, and how to create and use chokepoints on the map. The map is basically the same each night, but expands into a different area every few days. The variability from one level to the next therefore comes from differences in which enemies will attack, how many waves you'll face, and where on the map they'll all spawn. During the fight, you play in 3rd person perspective, luring enemies into your traps but also fighting them with your axe and rifle.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												  A very nice game. While story didn't grip me, mechanics easily carry the game. It's a mix of tactical trap-based defense and real time 3rd person cmbat.  By day you set up your traps, by night you run around while the waves spawn activating certain traps, luring monsters, simply fighting or panicking because something didn't go as planned and now you have an angry werewolf on your heels.   Even real time combat requires planing and tactics. You have to manage your stamina, musket amunition and reload (it's 19 century) utilise fear through fire and  well timed attacks. Intimidated enemies give you some time to aim, reload or catch breath because getting caught in a pack of even basic wolves will hurt.  The game offers huge amounts of gameplay variation - multiple traps, trap combinations, extensive skill tree to customise your playstyle. Clear waves without moving from your front porch? Funnel enemies around 1 big exploding barrel? Drop bait to keep them occupied until you and your new silver axe can catch up? Snipe from watchtower perch? Mix and match.  Mechanics are robust, soundtrack's nice, didn't notice any glitches or bugs (wave spawning notwhistanding).I highly recommend this game for unique mix of mechanics. And being "The most canadian game ever" ©TotalBiscuit.

Posted: September 13, 2013
												Described as "one of the most CANADIAN games you will ever play", Sang Froid is a story based defense game based upon the writings of a renowned French Canadian novelist (Bryan Perro). The game sets you in Quebec in the 1800s, setting you against the forces of wolves, werewolves, and other supnernatural opponents, forcing you to defend your sister and family from them using both your physical prowess and your knowledge of hunting and trapping. This isn't a tower defense; this is truly something worth playing for the ultimate, one man army strategist.

Posted: December 15, 2013
												I admit, the game looks a little rough around the edges, but it's a phenomenal take on tower defense games .The cutscenes are a little cheesy, the graphics aren't all that great, but the gameplay is unparalleled. Each 'mission' you have a set amount of money to spend on traps... the more efficient you are at not wasting money, the more money you can spend on better gear/upgrades/etc. This creates a sort of minimalist approach.. you're constantly trying to place as little traps as possible, and setting up a perfect wave by wave traps and backup plans that you can fall back on if something doesn't hit. The feeling of satisfaction you get when you pull of a perfectly planned 5+ wave defense is like nothing I've felt before in a game. Even when something goes amiss and you manage to pull through by the skin of your teeth.. it's great. There's enough RPG skill tree mechanics and 3rd person fighting skill to make it a lot more 'alive' then your normal TD game, too. Buy it! You won't regret it.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												This is a pretty fun game!  The theming is very well done, I like the vast majority of the artwork a whole lot, the music is awesome, and the gameplay is really enjoyable!  I would compare this game to something like Orcs Must Die!, but with slightly more emphasis on planning and strategy, and with a tiny bit of resource management (time units & money) to spice things up a little.I do acknowledge that this is an indie game, and I don't want to seem like I'm judging it unfairly, but my only real criticism of Sang-Froid is that I don't much care for the character model close-ups during the cutscenes (they are perfectly adequate for normal gameplay, however), and that I think better voice acting, perhaps with some/more exaggerated French-Canadian accents, would have gone a long way toward keeping with the terrific atmosphere the rest of the game is brimming with, and also toward justifying the $14.99 price tag.  Personally, I feel like that's ever-so-slightly high -- I would've purchased this game at some point before it went on sale, if the full price was closer to $9.99.  That said, this game is an absolute STEAL at the current sale price of $3.74!

Posted: February 1, 2014
												Every effort was made to try and not ruin the plot of the game throughout this review. However, no promises can be made.***Possible Spoilers follow***An amazing game for the price.  It is definitely unique, albeit a tad bit easy.  I started the game with Jos, although I really wanted Jack because I was hoping for more gunplay.  Changed to Jack after day 3 because it seemed a bit too easy to NOT play on the mode I had originally wanted.Although I found the gunplay severely lacking, I still enjoyed the game.  Honestly, aside from shooting Net traps or occasionally shooting enemies as they ran up, I rarely used my gun at all.  Even sitting on bonfires, I found it more advantageous to run out, do a full combo once or twice, and then run back into the saftey zone of the warming flames.However, when you think about it, that merges great with the historical and realistic (for a game about demons and werewolves) feel that the developers were trying to create. It wouldn't make much sense for you to be running around with a musket firing off round after round during the time period the game takes place in.I wasn't entirely thrilled by everything in the game though.  I spent a lot of the nights just sitting around waiting on my traps to go off and still using a good chunk of my AP on cutting lumber for money.  I actually found myself purposefully letting enemies get to my buildings each wave so I would have something to do.  If you understand how the traps work, you could literally clear almost every wave with traps alone.Overall the combat system itself was poorly made.  You get your "autoattack" consisting of left clicking up to 3 times for a combo (and with your stamina thats about 6-8 clicks until you fatigue) or rightclicking to spend your "rage" points. Once you learn the system its pretty childish.  Left click combo (3 clicks) to knock an enemy down, run / sprint in circles (run around and only sprint when they get close to avoid attack), and then combo again and repeat. Throw in an occasional Right-Click for a stamina-free attack/knockdown here and there. Doing this you could take on Wendigos and The Invisible Beast no problem. After around days 3-5 I never found myself using the roll (spacebar) except during fights with the "Fireflies". There was just no point in wasting all that stamina when a quick sprint away would dodge most if not all attacks and leave you with a lot more stamina.The "Fireflies" were probably the most annoying thing in the game.  Before you get the hang of fighting them, you will find youself constanly trying to take one down, only to find yourself slammed in the back by a fireball from another one and knocked down while the one you were fighting disappears underground to heal himself back up to full.  And thanks to the aforementioned combat system, you were really limited on your choices in fighting them with your axe.  Even once you learn how to fight them, you will still find yourself catching the occasional fireball and cursing at them.**Small spoilers**Which doesn't even matter towards the last few days of the game.  A very unique factor in the game was that enemies only took full damage from certain types of weapons (Normal, Blessed/Holy, or Silver).  So you had to decide what type of axe you wanted to bring with you or your types of bullets to stock up on (although as before, the gun is pretty useless unless you REALLY want to shoot something).  And then they add in THE AXE. Anyone who has played the game that far knows what I'm talking about, and others will know when they get there.This axe does full damage to everything. EVERYTHING. So now nothing is resistant anymore.  They basically took their system and threw it out the window for the last few days of the game, making the game even easier when it was supposed to be getting harder.  After you get the axe any combat is cake.  Wendigo? No problem (although a ballista will take it out in 1 shot with the skill point). I wouldn't recommend fighting a Wendigo hand-to-hand (because they cannot be knocked down, only backwards), but it is still pretty easy. And the Fireflies become cake. 15 Health? Kinda annoying to fight when they're resistant and can heal.  After the axe they go down in about 4 or 5 swings.**End Small Spoilers**A lot of the traps become obsolete later on as well. The wolf trap (20 AP and some money) is all well and good early on for insta-killing 1 wolf. Later on when the wolves come in packs of 3 there is little point to it. I put 1 point in trapping just so it would hold things (mainly Maikkans) for 10 seconds so I could set a spike trap and wait for more enemies to run up on the one stuck in place. Spike traps were better for the wolves because at 55 AP they save you AP and you can set them on the spawn point to drop the packs as soon as they zone in. The hanging nets become pretty much useless unless you want to use it on fireflies, and even then since it spreads the damage around between the enemies underneath you have to run up and finish them off.  I found that setting a Cross under a net, shouting, activating cross when they got near, letting it do some damage, and then dropping the trap was the best way for clearing a group of fireflies with minimum effort. And bonfires were pretty much useless because, as I mentioned earlier, you could get through almost every wave in the game without really having to fight anything if you set your traps right.**Small Ending Spoiler**And the ending itself was just, bleh.  There was no real feeling that you had finished the game.  It just ends like any other day in the game. There was no big feeling of triumph after you had finished it. It ends on a definite cliffhanger, but for the time put into the game the ending just isnt there. You get like 30 seconds of cutscene or so like you would any other day of the game.  You don't even reunite with the brother whose soul you saved. Everything was building up to you defeating this super demon and saving the village, you defeat it, and then thats it. A small cutscene, and its over.  Nothing about saving the village, saving your sister, saving your brother, nothing. It just ends, and rather poorly at that.  I even found myself googling the ending afterwards to see if I had missed something.**End Ending Spoiler**But all of that aside, there was something about the game that compelled me to finish it.  It could have been the gamer in me that didn't want to leave a game I had bought unbeaten. It could have been the uniqueness of the game itself.  But everything aside, I did find the game very enjoyable for the price and would recommend people to pick it up. Some people may want to wait to pick it up on sale (I got mine on sale) because although $15 for the game isnt a bad price at all, the game DOES lack a certain polish that would make it a must-have. I would definitely recommend that it at least gets placed on your wish list and for you to pick it up at some point, because it is definitely a unique and intriguing game even with the flaws in the game itself.I would like to see a sequel made, but the developers are really going to need to flesh it out a lot more to make it worthwhile, and the story is going to need to have some major work put into it. It felt like it was just a side thought to the game to spice it up a little bit in between the repititive nightly routine the game falls in to.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Sang-Froid appeals to me in a huge way, there is very little that I actually dislike about this game. The game is very creative and also innovative for games in general; adding interesting mechanics and ideas that are difficult to find in any other game!Simple things like having enemies able to fear you, smell you and hear you, make this game stand out from anything else you could find.What I like:- Great progression - The game is constantly adding new mechanics, enemies, traps and weapons, so it never becomes stale.- Planning - Allowing you to set up traps and decide what to defend during the day, and setting the plan in motion at night is a brilliant idea, and feels so rewarding when you accomplish the level.- The Lore - I usually don't pay attention to the setting of the games world, but Sang-Forid makes me care about the folk history, the overall aesthetic to the game is really amazing.- The Music - The music appeals to me in EVERY ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ WAY POSSIBLE, simply fantastic. It is also very fitting for the world it is set in!What I dislike/ could have been improved:- The story/ Dialogue - I am interested in the story, but due to the fact it was made by french developers the translation from French to English can sometimes come off poor or cheesy, not all the dialogue is bad though and most of the voice actors are actually quite good. It is sadly just not as strong as the rest of the game, but the fact that the developers were able to pull it off in the first place is a positive in my opinion!If you haven't guessed it already, I adore this game and would recommend it to anyone and everyone!

Posted: October 1, 2014
												This game manages something spectacular. It makes me realize how terrible it's graphics are in one moment and completely overlook it in the next, with its amazing gameplay and story.Simply said: Sang-Froid is a marvel of its kind. It chose a very underused setting, took its mentality, weapons and general feeling and turned it into an extremely challenging tower defense.This is no "Orcs must Die". Here you face just a hand full of enemies and you can plan all you want, which makes the strategic part much more rewarding. Since its the late 1800, your weapons are flintlock muskets and silvered hatchets, all while you fight to a great folk-song music. Now... there are some negatives... the cutscenes are terrible, making the still pictures look amazing. The game is relentlessly hard and combat is very stiff. Then again, you play as a lumberjack or a trapper, not a fighter. And still, it is incredibly rewarding to place your one bullet in a werewolf's head and frighten his comrades with a bonfire, while you watch your character shove your last holy bullet in the muzzle.

Posted: November 28, 2014
												One of the great little gems to shine out of the cacaphony overload of indie games on Steam. I grew up in minnesota, so when I saw werewolves, and canadian foklore, and RTS AND action...I hit the purchase button faster than a Wendigo sneezes ice. It has a great folky soundtrack, and great hand-drawn visuals, especially the menu and town interfaces. Being that it is indeed an indie game, the game budgets and amount of people working on this  title would be laughable to a mega-corp like Ubisoft or the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly EA. So there are a few expected rough areas, but they don't detract from the overall game. Mainly, the voice acting was terrible, I felt like random people off the street were pulled in to read children’s books to 1rst graders. If they every make a TOME II, it would be great if they addressed this. Conversely, the sounds while playing the game and the music are very well done. It really sends a shiver up your spine playing this in your room at night, the sounds of the wind rushing through trees, the crack of branches and snarls and howls of the beasts just over the hill expertly done to always create the feeling you will be attacked at any moment. Mechanically the game works pretty smooth, and is challenging to say the least. It creates tense and relentless action when you hit the go button; it actually is scary in a way. There is a sense of dread and nervousness as you hover your mouse over the ‘begin’ button…setting in motion the nights terrors upon you.  You hope things will work out and you will survive, but it always feels as if the odds are stacked against you. My one complaint is the pacing...the skill tree becoming unlocked only started to open up toward the end, and by the time I could really afford some better weapons, there were only a couple missions left. I wish there was a patch to adjust this a bit. I love a challenge, but I hate seeing cool things that I can't afford and can't have fun using, then it’s over. When it was over though, I can say it was definitely a sense of accomplishment! This makes me want to go back now, play with the harder brother and see if I can get those last few achievements, which are not just filler achievements.Overall, for a couple bucks, this game is well worth it, is unique, and hope to see their next game...though it looks vastly different in theme. A great 'first' game for this small team in Canada!

Posted: January 15, 2015
												SNAPSHOTAn action-RPG / tower defense game that looks like it was made by third graders. Thankfully, it plays like an 8th grade level.OVERALL - 3.5 / 10PROS+ combat feels responsive+ music is good+ planning each level is interesting+ relatively bug free (unless you're trying to get achievements, in which case the opposite of that)CONS- awful models (texturing is ok at best)- awful voice acting- awful writing- way too many game mechanics overly complicates almost every portion of the game- replaying levels *intentionally* disincentivized- every level uses the same map for the entire gameDETAILSWhere to even begin with this one. I really wanted to like Sang-Froid, I really did. Overall I like the concept of an action-RPG + tower defense game (Orcs Must Die! does it fairly well), and the movement in the game doesn't play all that poorly, but overall it is extremely poorly executed.Probably my biggest gripe is that combat-related gameplay itself is just a pile-on of systems that's only purposes seem to be to limit what the player can do. First there is stamina, which is a combined limit of being able to run as well as your ability to use melee combat. Melee is frustratingly bad, especially the targeting. Often times you'll be attacking an enemy that's about to die and then suddenly the game will switch targets on you and you'll be swinging at something else on the other side of the screen, leaving that low health enemy free to do whatever it wants (which 90% of the time means regen to full or cast a meteor swarm down on your face). It becomes even MORE frustrating when enemies start becoming ~90% resistant to normal damage, so unless you have a weapon the enemy is weak to you won't be doing full damage. Ranged combat requires you to reload after every single shot you take, which takes an inordinate amount of time (there's an *achievement* for reloading in under 3 seconds). You can speed up reloading slightly by mashing a button, which seems to only distract the player from how long it actually takes. Also of note for ranged combat is that it has headshot and non-headshot hitboxes that "lock on" (poorly) that are infuriating more often than not. Next, there's a "fear" system that was supposed to help players not fight enemies all the time, but in practice way too complicated and cumbersome. On top of all of this there are still traps for players to place, each of which only has *one* use per level (seriously?) per trap placed.Paired with this combat system is ~ 3 different enemies (there's one ranged enemy in the game, and then a few minor variations of a melee enemy) and *one* map that goes through extremely minor changes and expands slightly between levels. Also of note are the "two" characters to choose from, which in reality only vary in starting stats so I'm still not sure why the choice even exists. If there had been half as much time / effort put in to adding all the limiting factors in combat and 4x as much time put into adding real variations in content, it would have potentially been a much more engaging game. Unfortunately, while it seems all of the development efforts were spent in adding combat systems, combat gets old very quickly without a change in enemies to face. The different starting points and number of enemies each wave helps masks this problem slightly, but that wears thin pretty quickly.On top of all of this, replaying levels is almost completely out of the question. You CAN go back to a level you've already completed, however it erases ALL progress past that point. There is one achievement for completing the game for each character, but why anyone would do that is beyond me. The game doesn't play differently for either character, save for the fact that one of them has less health AND stamina than the other. Skill points that are awarded each time a player levels up only seem to annoy a player more than help them, most of which only add minor amounts of damage. The skill points spent almost never make a difference in whether or not an enemy dies; either the damage added is already overkill, or it adds such a minimal amount that you're better off walking up and meleeing them instead.Easily the worst parts of the game are the "animated cutscenes" between levels. I could forgive the awful models if there were a lot of them (or if this game was made in 2006), but there are comically few to be seen and it was released in 2013. It is very apparent that the entirety of the modeling / animation efforts in the game were spent on the cutscenes, which there are unfortunately ~1-3 of every single level. The voice acting is as cringe-worthy as the models, and the writing is almost as bad. Given that the story is based on French Canadian folklore, however, that means 90% of the work was already done story-wise, so how that was screwed up so poorly I'll never know.Overall, this game has a lot of things in place to distract players from the fact that just about every system was poorly planned and designed, so if you're really into shiny things feel free to pick it up. If you're not easily fooled, however, stay as far away as you can.

Posted: May 20, 2013
												A continuing evolution of the Tower Defense + OTS Combat genre, Sang-Froid strikes an amazing balance between so many different gameplay elements. A dark and well crafted story weaves the campaign together and keeps you engaged from start to finish. During the day you can examine the types of monsters that will attack during the next night and the routes they'll take. You then use your time units and money to place traps. Leftover time can be used to generate additional funds, which can be spent in the town on weapons, ammo, trinkets, and consumables. By tying money and time together, Sang-Froid forces you to make tough decisions when planning your day. It's a balance between putting the bare-minimum of traps down so you can afford upgrades without getting yourself killing the process. Combat at night is fun and tense, with good controls and a variety of monsters that need special tactics to take down. You'll find yourself juggling defending different objectives and, once again, your greatest enemy is time as you fight to clear one attack as quickly as possible so you can make it to the next objective in time. Over-all a great game on many levels, and a must-buy for anyone that enjoys Tower Defense, werewolves, or strategic OTS combat.

Posted: March 31, 2014
												As this is on sale now I though I might give a short recommendation. This game is possibly the most unique strategy game I've seen. It offers a wide variety of innovative and unique gameplay mechanics. The levels play as both a tower defense puzzle where you place elaborate traps around the map in order to take enemies out passively, and as an RPG with strategy components where you engage the enemies actively with rifle and axe. The fear meter is a very interesting mechanic where the actions of the enemy depend on the amount of fear both you and your enemies have. For the discounted price (€2,- here) this game is absolutely worth it. It is also the most Canadian game ever.

Posted: March 9, 2014
												Unique setting, simple but not dull combat as the combination of traps and weapons keeps things fresh... all in all, an excellent little effort. And I do mean little; it takes place over twenty days, meaning twenty levels, and then it's done. On the downside, the voice acting is mediocre, though not "Oh dear sweet Cthulhu devour my mind that I may be free of this torment" level (see: Disciples 3, Dawn of War). Seriously, though, you've set your game in frontier Canada, your main characters are French-Canadian, and you couldn't find any Quebecois to help with any of the voice acting? All the same, this game is a throwback to classics like The Horde and its newer versions in Orcs Must Die and other tower defense FPSs, and is fun, compelling, and challenging. Totally worth one's $15.

												Misleading is the best summary I can give. From the trailer, it looked like a great hack and slash with tactical planning, but ended up having Rainbow Six bloopers where if you don't do everything perfectly, you are screwed.The graphics are pretty good. They remind me of a  launch title for the PS2. I don't like how little I can adjust the graphics and because of the lowest settings available, it isn't fluid for frame rates (I hover around 40 instead of the preferred 60). I can't even adjust the resolution outside of my monitor (16:10), so I'm forced to 1244x800 instead of picking something lower when there are options to select lower.The reaction times for attack animations are a bit off. The stamina bar affects attack speed, but creatures like the werewolf tended to almost blink towards me like a flash step and I couldn't swing to counter attack in time. Things like that prevent  a lot tactical fighting, especially when certain creatures like the Were-wolf are too fast to run away from and you'll pretty much die if you don't strike first with a trap.Sound effects are passable. I wanted to listen to my own music fairly quickly, but the intro song alone was pretty good while it took two full minutes to load on a fairly modern machine. (made in 2011 with the latest parts at the time).All together it is frustrating to the point I don't want to spend too much time replaying levels because of the inability for the characters to be useful. It is Rainbow Six all over again and the old Rainbox Six games were cool atmosphere but quit-inducing rage sessions due to bad AI and weird decisions from the Devs for gameplay, just like this game.

Posted: October 2, 2014
												Having picked this up for just a couple dollars during a Steam sale I can honestly say I am not sure if I've ever received this much enjoyment for so little money. I had spotted the game on Greenlight many months ago and was intrigued by the novel and clever premise for a hybrid strategy/tactics/action. Even then at the 15 dollar mark I was strongly considering the purchase if the game turned out to be good fun. Sadly, the game flew in under my radar on release and I forgot all about it until I noticed it at the top of the User Review list on the Steam sales page. You play as one of two brothers living in the woods on the outskirts of Wolvesdale, somewhere in Canada. The winters are harsh here and the prowling wolves even harsher. Lil' Jos, the burly big brother is more than capable of whopping wolves with his axe, shooting them with his musket, and setting traps. The other Brother, Jack, is a more frail sort and you will have to lean heavily on your ingenuity with traps to succeed with Jack as your choice. At the start of the game you are first introduced to Jack and soon thereafter, Jos and their sister Josephine. Josephine has come down with a fever after a travesty at the local church parish involving the pastor. I won't spoil the story for you, as it does a fine job of effortlessly tossing the Christian and pagan at you without being heavy handed or conciously offensive. Christian motifs figure prominently in the story as well as pagan and Native American belief. The characters are well done and push the story along quite well. Josephine begins to prophecy foreboding events and the two brothers resolve to get her to town for medical treatment. After the nearby bridge has mysteriously burned down, events begin to domino toward ever more sinister happenings. You'll face two varieties of wolves, 2 varieties of werewolves, and a handful of other mythical creatures such as the Amerindian 'Maikan" which amounts to their verison of the werewolf myth, as well as Will-o-Wisps and the like. The Devil plays a major role and is puppetering the corrupted pastor and townsfolk to play out his wicked game in an attempt to destroy the townsfolk, the brothers and their sister. The writing is solid and the voice acting is competent. I'm enjoying the cutscenes story unfold into the missions you are tasked with. The main game consists of a pre-game tactical strategy map where you purchase and place any number of devious traps to incapacitate and dispose of the hellish fiends. The game has a good learning curve and introduces you to the myriad devices slowly; as it should. This aspect of the game is very reminiscient of the Bullfrog Dungeon Master games of years gone by. Great fun is to be had plotting your tactics to deal with the many waves of enemies that are tasked with destroying your assorted buildings. To write of all the many traps and how to use them would amount to a miniature FAQ and so I will leave much of that to you, dear reader, to research. To say the developers gave you a treasure trove of gadgets is putting it mildly. At the beginning of each match you are also able to use the money you acquire from defeating the creatures to purchase better weapons, ammo and gear. A coventry nearby can bless your bullets or axes, respectively, so as to deal greater damage to the diabloical creatures. The general store sells an ever increasing number of muskets that have authentic descriptions of their real world counterparts with some very nifty trivia thrown in. You also can purchase new gear and ammo. And the hotel furnishes you with an assortment of liquors that have varying effects on your character in battle.During the match proper, you will be scurrying as your very life does depend on it. Following the routes you planned during the pre-game phase you will have to be front and center for certain traps to be effective. The deadly net trap requires you to shoot the net and drop it on the creatures below. If you have a bait present under the net you simply take your time and fire. Otherwise, you'll have to get crafty and 'shout' for your enemy to come inspect the area. Bonfires help buff the 'fear factor' that  keeps the creatures at a distance as they prowl slowly around you looking to strike. During this time you can reload your musket and go for the headshot without worrying about being ripped to shreds.  Fire walls can be strategically placed to alter the route of your enemy. Watchtowers with ziplines to other parts of the map are a lifesaver when you need to 'be there' quickly to prevent destruction of your precious buildings. This is only a smattering of the many traps available. Nevermind all the possibilities on how to use them in conjunction with each other.And I haven't even touched on the player levels. Much like an RPG, you earn experience points that allow you to upgrade many traits. Typical character buffs like more health, stamina, and the like as well as quicker reloading and stronger traps are available. But there are also quite a few unique buffs such as poisoned bait that damages the devouring creature or increasing the damage done as a 'sniper' if you should decide to try for a shot from one of your watchtowers. I could go on and on about all the neat features of this game with impunity. The game is well balanced and is a blast to play once you grasp the game mechanics. Most of the game elements will feel familiar to the hobby gamer. But by combining them in such a manner requires an enjoyable pause for thought that many modern games no longer ask of you. To have my intelligence and keyboard savvy simultaneously challenged has been a real treat.  The art style is charming and the music very well done. The graphics are rather modest for a modern game and have a World of Warcraft nature to them but serve the game quite well.  Artifice Studio is officially on my list of promising developers to watch. I cannot recommend this game strongly enough. Especially for the money. A MUST BUY!

Posted: December 8, 2014
												I'll admit I was very wary of this game when I took my first glimpse in it's direction. While othing seemed mechanicly wrong with the game from the get go, nothing really stood out to me either as anything worthwhile. However with a recent sale, and a good friend of mine recomending it every chance he got, I decided to pick the game of and give it an honest chanceThe first thing I'll mention aout the game is that while the combat has a clunky feel to it, it's surprisingly enjoyable and really fits the theme of the game, if theirs any time I found myself frustrated with an outcome in combat it was because I hadn't managed properly and felt the weight of it come crashing down on me. You play one of two lumberjacks fighting the Devil and his werewolf, spirit army. Pretty badass concept but it's up to you to be the badass of the story, the game won't do it for you.Resource management is key to winning this game, and the trap and resource system is set up harsh but fairly. You really need to pay atention to what your actually able to spend on upgrading your personal gear like weapons, protective clothing and consumables, because while a good axe or rifle may come in handy, they only help you against one or two enemies before your overwhelmed, however a proper trap could take out four enemies in one go, nothing beats a properly executed trap.The game also has a fear system, allowing you to scare off certain enemies , and help even the odds against the packs of wolves that often surround you. Alot of enjoyment is to be found making your enemies hesitate to atack you and start having to size you up before their confident enough to strike again.Lastly but cerainly not least is the soundtrack to this game. This game has one of the best soundracks I've ever heard. It definitely has music you can stomp your foot to (I speak from experience on this.) The music of this game brings everything to another lvel, it makes combat even more enoyable, it gives you a goo sense of the world, and it's just plain fun to listen too.In short Sang-Froid is a challenging but rewarding game that offers fun gameplay, a badass story, and some of the best music you'll ever hear in a video game, if not just in general. I'd recomend this game to anyone who likes a nice challenge and is a fan of strategy. I'd give Sang-Froid an 8/10. It's not the highest budjet game, but you most certainly et your dollars worth for it, most of that with the soundtrack alone.

Posted: December 5, 2014
												One of the most underrated games of 2013, Sang-froid has absolutely amazing and fresh game design. It cleverly brings the gameplay elements one at a time to let you get familiar with each of them but it's up to you to truly understand how to master the game and to develop strategy to survive each night. The game is super well balanced, never too much nor too little money. Just enough to get by, and successful plans feel greatly rewarding. With that Sang-froid explores a really nice part of the canadian folklore. The music match that mood perfectly and do a great job at immersing you in the game. The one and only thing I can criticize about the game truly is the quality of the voice acting, the 3D models and the animations. It doesnt really get in the way except during the cutscenes. The rest is bloody brilliant.

Posted: December 8, 2015
												Sang Froid is a wonderful Indie game. To quickly sum up this game, it's an action-based tower defense with a story tacked on to boot.  You set up your traps during the day and defend your buildings at night using traps, axe, and rifle. The monsters come in waves and you need to set up your traps and your positioning to respond to the monsters and their path (which you can later manipulate).Combine that with a levelling system (arguably on rails as if you survive the night, you'll level but even in failure, you can level up) in which I have yet to find a single ability which wouldn't be useful depending on playstyle. There are two playable characters which determine the difficulty of the game. Jos is a tough strong guy whereas his brother Jack is better with a gun but not as tough. I had a really good time with this game however, there was not a great deal of play time available. You need to survive 20 nights and the story completes itself. There are plans for a Sang Froid 2 however, the company just released Conflicks on Steam and the follow up might be a while in the making.  I would also have loved perhaps some more choice in the story but for their first effort, Sang Froid was a gem. I would give it a 8.5 out of 10 but totally worth your time and money.

Posted: January 11, 2015
												Nice indie tower defence game. Took around 20-30hrs of playtime to 100%. Much of the playtime is used in formulating a strategy for the upcoming night; determining which traps to use, where to place them, and how to create and use chokepoints on the map. The map is basically the same each night, but expands into a different area every few days. The variability from one level to the next therefore comes from differences in which enemies will attack, how many waves you'll face, and where on the map they'll all spawn. During the fight, you play in 3rd person perspective, luring enemies into your traps but also fighting them with your axe and rifle.

												Here is the most canadian game ever made, and what a joy it is to play.  If you liked Orcs must die, you will probably love this game.  Each day you prapare your battle plan, set up traps, study enemy routes, and spend the rest of your time getting a bit of money for weapons and gear.Then night falls..  What follows is then a hectic, fast paced dance of blood and steel as you run around activating each part of your plan, seeing it in motion, and hopefully killing your foes before they destroy everything.This is not an easy game, but when you survive a night by the skin of your teeth, burying your axe into the last enemy, it will be a victory worth cheering.

Posted: December 15, 2013
												I admit, the game looks a little rough around the edges, but it's a phenomenal take on tower defense games .The cutscenes are a little cheesy, the graphics aren't all that great, but the gameplay is unparalleled. Each 'mission' you have a set amount of money to spend on traps... the more efficient you are at not wasting money, the more money you can spend on better gear/upgrades/etc. This creates a sort of minimalist approach.. you're constantly trying to place as little traps as possible, and setting up a perfect wave by wave traps and backup plans that you can fall back on if something doesn't hit. The feeling of satisfaction you get when you pull of a perfectly planned 5+ wave defense is like nothing I've felt before in a game. Even when something goes amiss and you manage to pull through by the skin of your teeth.. it's great. There's enough RPG skill tree mechanics and 3rd person fighting skill to make it a lot more 'alive' then your normal TD game, too. Buy it! You won't regret it.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												I got this for $7.49 during a sale. Warning: This is a indie title. If you can't stand games that are not perfect, turn around now.Gameplay: You play as one of any two brothers that each night fight to defend their cabin as well as other buildings as you progress. Each night you prepare your map from a top down perspective by putting down traps and obstacles to slow down, damage, and/or kill waves of   werewolves and other creatures. During this time you can also travel to the nerby village to buy supplies(a hub of storefronts). Here buy drinks that heal or give you bonus, supplies, and upgrades your weapons(axe and rifle). When you are ready the night begins and you are put into third person to fight each wave.The story/animation/voice acting is what you would expect of a indie game. Not terrible, but not that amazing.If this is for around $5 and don't mind something differen't, give this game a shot. It is one of those gems you never hear about.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Sang-Froid is a really interesting and innovative hybrid action-strategy game. Each level consists of a planning/strategy phase where you spend time & money to set up traps followed by an action phase where you attempt to defeat the wolves & other enemies with your traps, axe, and musket, earning money for each kill. The voice acting is uneven but none of it's nails-on-chalkboard, the difficulty curve is very smooth, and the in-game tutorials are quite adequate. Also, fun.

Posted: July 18, 2015
												This is actually quite a fantastic little game.  Though it only took me roughly 4-5 hours to beat, I only played through once.   (you get to play through a second time as "the other brother", which easily doubles, if not tripples the gametime).  The first part of every night in this game is the trap set-up.  This takes a bit of thinking, and in later levels might rack your brain a bit (which is a good thing for all puzzle games).  The second part of every night is where you actually fight the werewolves and other nasties, making sure your traps function properly... and you'll know if they don't.  Admitedly, the last level (boss) frusterated me quite a bit, but after...  A dozen tries, and looking up a walktrhough I managed to get it.  I'll go ahead and spill the beans on that, to prevent frustation for any future players;  The boss (the invisible beast) can only be killed with your sister's blood on a bullet.  Assuming you make it to the boss, and you use your glasses to "see" him, AND you beat him up...  He'll get beat  up until 0 health, then he'll stand there dizzy for a matter of seconds (it's very fast).  Shoot quick with your blood-bullet while he's dizzy and at 0 health, and don't miss!  Or he'll regenerate, and you'll have to beat him up all over again!That being said (even with that minor frusteration), this game is certainly worth taking a look at, and was fun and frusterating (in a good way) - after all, if a game's no challenge, what's the point?

Posted: August 5, 2013
												Brilliant. Combines strategy and action delightfully, and with intensity I would not have guessed. Each level works out to 2 minutes in the shops, 45 minutes of planning, a short derailment to fix a boneheaded mistake, 5 minutes of action, and a bit of exhaustion.Plot aspects are a bit puppet-show-y, but adequate. The characters are simple, but none are worthless. It's hard to be annoyed at having to protect someone who helps you lay more traps. It is the struggle of siblings against a grave threat, with both the problem and the solution enhanced by different members of the community.The gameplay is interesting, and absolutely astounding how much the designers give you with so few resources. From manipulating sound and scent to lure your foes into traps and ambushes, to simply running away to regroup, reload, or activate some fun toy you left for a fallback. So many sensible options to choose from... I haven't had a game stretch my tactical thinking like this in a very long time.I raise all the thumbs I have to this game.

Posted: April 27, 2016
												"Sang-Froid - Tales of Werewolves" is a fusion of tower-defense, strategy and action genres, that gets all its elements JUST right. Set in mid 19th century in Quebec, the game is a delight to play and for the most part, is amazingly immersive. First, here is a brief about each of the three genre elements:Tower-defense: The game follows the standard "place towers --> defend against waves" profile. You place defensive and offensive traps in the day, to defend 1 to 5 of your buildings (the number increases from 1 to 5 over 13 levels) in the night. The traps are varied, paths are all well marked, and variation in enemies is also good. The map is amazingly good in global top-down view as well as the zoomed in 3rd person warcraft-like view. No level is frustratingly bad/difficult but each level takes a certain amount of smarts from the players.Strategy: The number of factors you have to account for is quite considerable. Placing traps not only take money, they also take up action points. Each day has a set maximum of action points. This makes sure that even if you save up money, the game doesn't become lame easy. Money in itself is pretty tight, at least for the first half. Wanting to buy better gear forces really effficient trap placements. Health, stamina, fear factor, weapons, potions, and later on even wearable items come into play (more on that in next point). Your character also levels up slowly so you can improve certain attributes; however you level up barely 16-17 times and the skill tree has ~40 skills. Thus, this aspect acts as customization suited to your own playstyle. Overall, I was pleasantly surprised by the depth and balance of strategy.Action: This is the twist factor of the game, and in my opinion, really what makes the game shine. The strategy and tower defense alone were enough actually to make a whole game. But after you place the traps and the night begins you yourself go out with your axe and your gun, carrying potions, items, and 3 types of bullets with you. This aspect adds a LOT of playtime to the game, and makes you execute the traps you placed in the day. You also see your planning unfold in front of you as waves after waves of enemies fall to your cunning traps. There are certain fixed outposts for fast travel as many times waves have enemies rushing in to many buildings simultaneously. The later enemies especially need to be dealt with manually, and there are many traps that make it easier for you - one damage over time, one shooting fireballs, and even a bonfire that temporarily makes the enemies "fear" you. The wind direction also plays a role as your scent is carried to the enemies with the wind. If you are at the wrong place at the wrong time, enemies halfway across the map will smell you and run to you and abandon their fixed paths, wasting your traps and probably killing you.  Again, A+ to the devs for great execution and seamless fusion of first person action with strategy.Pros:-Solid mechanics, no bugs, just the right length to give a satisfying experience while being fun-Great balance of all ingredients along with all-round balanced strategy elements-Immersive atmosphere, all thanks to amazing folk music selection played at precisely the right pace-Two difficullties (so slight replay value)-Achievements are decent, they give a kind of "special" challenge, nothing gimmicky-Responsive devs (on Steam forum, that I know of)Cons:-Voice acting, dialogues and cutscenes in general are the weaker points of the game; nothing game breaking but if the devs were short on cash/talent they could've forwarded the story using comic strip format (like Max Payne), narration format (like the intro video of the game) or maybe even plain written story format-Apart from that, I just found the last 20% of the game slightly monotonous, the reasons being:As you proceed in the game and if you are half-decent you have a stockpile of cash even after buying all the best gear for the last 5 levelsAlong with that, if you're buying all potions from the start and hoarding them, just axe-hacking most waves becomes an easier way out by the end and ridiculously so with the right perksLast 5 levels are just 5-6 waves of repeated enemies, no noveltySumming up all 3 points, I think the devs could've had waves with enemies swarming in large numbers by the end levels that would force liberal cash usage and disallow you from brute-forcing it by making you impossibly outnumberedApart from those nitpicks, the game is really innovative and near-perfect.Final verdict: Recommended!8.5/10, well worth the full price.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												Игра стоящая. За такую цену со скидкой в 75% стоит взять. Лично я жду продолжения. Рекомендую всем.*****This game is very good. By the spirit, by the story, by gameplay as well. Its not a project you will play for months like Skyrim, but this game grants you a lot of positive emotions. Gameplay divides into 3 parts: something like RPG where you research some new skills, manage your money to purchase new traps and weapon. The 2nd is to place the traps on the map and planning your fight against enemies (which are different by abilities and combat tactics). The 3rd one is fighting itself in the manner of tower defence with an actie character (you may choose one of two brothers) you play by.Especially I like the story, seems its inspired by Washington Irwing tales. It touchs you. By this hot price EVERYONE who interest the games should try it. I recommend hardly. I bet you'll enjoy it. I wait for the continue of this game in production now. The music is AWESOME! True irish folk tracks.

Posted: March 4
												Truly a phenomominal game. I have never seen a game set up quite like this one. The story is great, Atmosphere is well set, Tactics is absolutely crucial. (If you run in and try to gun everything without utilizing your traps you will die in the worst possible way you can imagine.) Quite challenging in some levels requiring careful planning which is excelente if you enjoy a challenge in your games. But by far the best thing about this game. (At least in my opinion.) Is the soundtrack. The sound track for Sanfroid is by far the greatest sound track i've heard for any game i've played so far! It would be absolutely silly to not give this game a shot. I guarantee you would absolutely love this game! I will be absolutely thrilled when sangfroid tome 2 comes out! Happy hunting lads! (Note: Please disregard the ammount of hours i have put into this game at the time of posting I've had a bad computer for years so when i run it it has been very choppy but with my new rig it runs like a dream perfect so be expecting to see a LOT more hours out of me!)
